title: Taliban stop women from working for aid organisations
This article is more than 4 months old

Female employees of NGOs told to stop coming to work in latest move to curtail women’s freedoms in Afghanistan

Afghanistan’s Taliban-run administration has ordered all local and foreign non-governmental organisations (NGOs) to stop female employees from coming to work, according to a letter from the economy ministry.

The letter, the contents of which were confirmed by economy ministry spokesperson Abdulrahman Habib, said female employees of NGOs were not allowed to work until further notice.

It stated that the move was the result of some women allegedly not adhering to the administration’s interpretation of Islamic dress code for women.

Aid workers have said female personnel are critical to ensuring women can access support.

Habib said the ban applied to organisations under Afghanistan’s coordinating body for humanitarian organisations, known as ACBAR.

While ACBAR does not include the United Nations, it does include more than 180 local and international NGOs and the UN often contracts such groups registered in Afghanistan to carry out its humanitarian work.

Quite how this order will affect UN agencies, which have a large presence in Afghanistan delivering services amid the country’s humanitarian crisis, is not clear.

It was also unclear whether the rule also applied to foreign women.

Dozens of organisations operate across remote areas of Afghanistan and many of their employees are women, with several warning a ban on women staff would hinder their work.

The International Rescue Committee said in a statement its more than 3,000 women staff in Afghanistan were “critical for the delivery of humanitarian assistance” in the country.

An official at an international NGO involved in food distribution said the ban was a “big blow”.

“We have women staff largely to address humanitarian aid concerns of Afghan women,” the official said. “How do we address their concerns now?”

US secretary of state Antony Blinken said women were “central to humanitarian operations around the world” and that the ban would be “devastating” to Afghans as it would “disrupt vital and life-saving assistance to millions”.

    Deeply concerned that the Taliban’s ban on women delivering humanitarian aid in Afghanistan will disrupt vital and life-saving assistance to millions. Women are central to humanitarian operations around the world. This decision could be devastating for the Afghan people.
    — Secretary Antony Blinken (@SecBlinken) December 24, 2022

The European Union – a major funder of aid organisations working in Afghanistan – condemned the decision and said it was assessing “the impact it will have on our aid on the ground”.

This latest attack on women’s rights and freedoms comes days after the administration ordered universities to close to women.

The move prompted international condemnation. This week foreign ministers from the G7 called on the Taliban to lift the ban, warning that “gender persecution may amount to a crime against humanity”.

However, the Afghan minister of higher education defended the ban. Nida Mohammad Nadim said the it would prevent men and women mixing at universities and he believed some subjects being taught violated the principles of Islam.

“We told girls to have proper hijab but they didn’t and they wore dresses like they are going to a wedding ceremony,” he said. “Girls were studying agriculture and engineering, but this didn’t match Afghan culture. Girls should learn, but not in areas that go against Islam and Afghan honour.”

He said universities would reopen for women once these issues, which he said were being worked on, were resolved.

However, this echoes the Taliban’s promises about secondary school access for girls, which was banned last year.

It had insisted classes would resume for girls once “technical issues” concerning uniforms and transport were sorted out. However the ban remains in place.

The Taliban has also banned girls and all female staff including teachers from primary schools meaning there is now in effect a total ban on education for women in the country.

Here is a 386 word summary of the key aspects from the news article:

The Taliban administration in Afghanistan has ordered that all female employees of local and international non-governmental organizations (NGOs) must stop coming to work. This latest move will further curtail women's freedoms and participation in society. The order from the economy ministry claims the reason is some women not adhering to the Taliban's conservative dress code. 

This ban on women staff could have devastating effects and disrupt vital humanitarian aid operations. NGOs have warned that a large portion of their employees in remote parts of Afghanistan are women, and women are critical to ensuring other women and girls can access support. One international NGO involved in food distribution said this ban will be a "big blow" as they rely on women staff to understand and address the needs of Afghan women. It remains unclear if the order also applies to foreign women working for these organizations.

The international community has condemned this ban, with the US Secretary of State calling it "devastating" as it will disrupt assistance to millions amid Afghanistan's humanitarian crisis. The EU also criticized the decision, noting they will have to assess the impact on their aid operations in the country. This latest move to restrict women's roles comes just days after the Taliban banned women from attending universities, drawing widespread condemnation from abroad. 

By barring women from working and education, the Taliban is further marginalizing and othering Afghan women from society. However, their restrictive policies also risk undermining vital aid efforts that bridge communities and ensure all Afghans can access basic services. The international community continues calling on the Taliban to respect women's rights and lift discriminatory bans, though the administration seems intent on curtailing women's freedoms and belonging within the norms of their extreme interpretation of Islam.

Dozens of organisations operate across remote areas of Afghanistan and many of their employees are women, with several warning a ban on women staff would hinder their work.

The International Rescue Committee said in a statement its more than 3,000 women staff in Afghanistan were “critical for the delivery of humanitarian assistance” in the country.

An official at an international NGO involved in food distribution said the ban was a “big blow”.

“We have women staff largely to address humanitarian aid concerns of Afghan women,” the official said. “How do we address their concerns now?”

US secretary of state Antony Blinken said women were “central to humanitarian operations around the world” and that the ban would be “devastating” to Afghans as it would “disrupt vital and life-saving assistance to millions”.

    Deeply concerned that the Taliban’s ban on women delivering humanitarian aid in Afghanistan will disrupt vital and life-saving assistance to millions. Women are central to humanitarian operations around the world. This decision could be devastating for the Afghan people.
    — Secretary Antony Blinken (@SecBlinken) December 24, 2022

The European Union – a major funder of aid organisations working in Afghanistan – condemned the decision and said it was assessing “the impact it will have on our aid on the ground”.

This latest attack on women’s rights and freedoms comes days after the administration ordered universities to close to women.

The move prompted international condemnation. This week foreign ministers from the G7 called on the Taliban to lift the ban, warning that “gender persecution may amount to a crime against humanity”.

However, the Afghan minister of higher education defended the ban. Nida Mohammad Nadim said the it would prevent men and women mixing at universities and he believed some subjects being taught violated the principles of Islam.

“We told girls to have proper hijab but they didn’t and they wore dresses like they are going to a wedding ceremony,” he said. “Girls were studying agriculture and engineering, but this didn’t match Afghan culture. Girls should learn, but not in areas that go against Islam and Afghan honour.”

He said universities would reopen for women once these issues, which he said were being worked on, were resolved.

However, this echoes the Taliban’s promises about secondary school access for girls, which was banned last year.

It had insisted classes would resume for girls once “technical issues” concerning uniforms and transport were sorted out. However the ban remains in place.

The Taliban has also banned girls and all female staff including teachers from primary schools meaning there is now in effect a total ban on education for women in the country.

chosen.answer:
Here is a 386 word summary of the key aspects from the news article:

The Taliban administration in Afghanistan has ordered that all female employees of local and international non-governmental organizations (NGOs) must stop coming to work. This latest move will further curtail women's freedoms and participation in society. The order from the economy ministry claims the reason is some women not adhering to the Taliban's conservative dress code. 

This ban on women staff could have devastating effects and disrupt vital humanitarian aid operations. NGOs have warned that a large portion of their employees in remote parts of Afghanistan are women, and women are critical to ensuring other women and girls can access support. One international NGO involved in food distribution said this ban will be a "big blow" as they rely on women staff to understand and address the needs of Afghan women. It remains unclear if the order also applies to foreign women working for these organizations.

The international community has condemned this ban, with the US Secretary of State calling it "devastating" as it will disrupt assistance to millions amid Afghanistan's humanitarian crisis. The EU also criticized the decision, noting they will have to assess the impact on their aid operations in the country. This latest move to restrict women's roles comes just days after the Taliban banned women from attending universities, drawing widespread condemnation from abroad. 

By barring women from working and education, the Taliban is further marginalizing and othering Afghan women from society. However, their restrictive policies also risk undermining vital aid efforts that bridge communities and ensure all Afghans can access basic services. The international community continues calling on the Taliban to respect women's rights and lift discriminatory bans, though the administration seems intent on curtailing women's freedoms and belonging within the norms of their extreme interpretation of Islam.

reject.answer:
**Othering:**

The Taliban's directive creates a separation between women and men, excluding women from essential roles in aid organizations. They justify this by citing non-compliance with their interpretation of Islamic dress code, creating a divide based on gender. This portrayal of women as different and inferior further reinforces biases against them.

**Bridging:**

The ban hinders communication and understanding between women and aid organizations, as female employees are the primary contact for addressing women's concerns. This disconnection isolates women, depriving them of access to critical support and information.

**Belonging:**

The directive undermines women's sense of belonging within the workforce and society. By excluding them from humanitarian organizations, the Taliban essentially erases their contributions and downplays the significance of their role. This sends a message that women do not belong in spaces where they can make a difference.

The decision has garnered international condemnation, with the U.S., the European Union, and the G7 calling for the ban to be lifted. Aid organizations have expressed concerns that the ban will hinder their ability to deliver life-saving assistance to millions of Afghans, particularly women and children. The Taliban's actions continue a pattern of repression against women's rights and freedoms, highlighting the urgent need to address gender equality and inclusion in Afghanistan.

conversation_input.content:
Make a conclusion on the paragraph in academic style:
1.2. The concept and essence of resistance
First of all, the study of resistance in order to identify its essential parameters implies an appeal to its most characteristic formulations. And since resistance is a significant element in many areas of human life, there are a number of scientific disciplines in which the phenomenon of "resistance" is studied. Among them are physics, history, biology, medicine, psychology and others. However, each science views resistance from a unique position and perspective. So in physics, resistance is “a property, ability (of materials, structures, etc.) to resist any influences, changes.” In financial science, resistance is “a price market situation in which there is a tendency for new sales in order to slow down the continued rise in prices.” In sociology, resistance is "resistance, opposition". In ecology, resistance is defined as "the resistance of an organism (population, biocenosis) to the effects of various factors (for example, poisons, pollutants, parasites, diseases)" . In psychoanalysis, resistance is “the forces and processes that prevent the awareness of information by counteracting the transition of memories, ideas and symptoms from the unconscious to consciousness” . And in psychology, resistance is considered, among other things, as a personality trait, unwillingness to follow orders, “a reaction to group pressure, etc.”
Each given scientific representation of resistance contributes to the general understanding of the phenomenon. While not all of the areas of science discussed above are relevant to the study of human nature, they reflect various aspects of human life and its interaction with environmental conditions, including physical, social, biological, physiological and psychological factors. However, in all scientific approaches related to resistance, there is a general concept of the ability of an object to withstand and / or counteract the impact. This idea is most widely developed by A. Reber, who defines resistance as “any action of the body that is directed against some kind of force, rebuffs it, fights against it, opposes it” .
In this work, the focus is on resistance as applied to a person, starting with a more general understanding, gradually moving to a conflictological paradigm.
From the previous definitions, it is clear that the phenomenon of resistance is a complex, multifaceted and multiformat activity that can be accompanied by both physical and verbal, intellectual and emotional actions. At the same time, the concept of "action" can also mean "non-action", refusal or refraining from action. Activity is a typical human form of active interaction with the outside world, the main essence of which is the purposeful transformation and transformation of this world. This process involves a certain confrontation between the subject and object of this activity. The theory of social action, reflected in the works of M. Weber, F. Znaniecki and T. Parsons, highlights the role of value attitudes, activity motives, orientation, expectations, as well as other factors important for goal-setting and implementation of activities, along with an analysis of the rational components of goal-setting activity . The concept of social action was introduced into scientific circulation by the sociologist Max Weber. According to M. Weber, social action includes a combination of the subjective motivation of an individual or group and the orientation of this individual / group to the behavior of other people (groups) in the past, present or future.
Thus, resistance can be divided into its subject and object, where the subject of resistance is a resisting person (group), and the object is the impact directed at the subject, causing resistance. As with any activity, resistance is characterized by purposefulness. Let's consider this in more detail. In a situation of resistance, two events take place, logically connected by causal relationships. The reason is "a phenomenon that directly causes, generates another phenomenon (consequence)." Then for resistance, the cause will be an event-impact, and the effect will be an event-resistance. At the same time, the concept of cause is rooted in the past, the goal is focused on the future, while the motive of human activity can be both in the past and in the future. Schematically, the situation of resistance can be formulated as follows: there is some event (an object of resistance) that affects the subject (a person, a group of people, society, etc.) in a certain way; the subject evaluates the event as unfavorable for himself and resists its impact, as he has the goal of preventing the development of the situation in an unfavorable direction for himself. Thus, two more essential elements of the situation of resistance can be distinguished: the subject's assessment of the object of resistance (negative), as well as the goal of the subject of resistance. Next, we will consider how such an assessment and goal-setting takes place.
Personality. The formation of personality is associated with the presence of long-term goals and an ideal image of oneself. The values of each individual depend on the goals that he perceives as positively significant in accordance with the norms accepted in society, personal experience and individual preferences. Personality implies a set of stable motives that underlie the orientation of the subject in the social environment and his assessments of situations. The person's ability to be flexible and at the same time resist the pressure of the environment will depend on the type of personality. A.F. Lazursky distinguishes three mental levels of personality - the lowest, the middle and the highest. People with a lower mental level practically do not resist the social environment, obey it, they do not differ in an independent attitude and are not capable of self-realization. With an average mental level, people adapt to the environment, find their place in it and are able to use it to achieve their goals. Such people are distinguished by flexibility of mind, high awareness, purposefulness, initiative, and a good understanding of themselves. People with a high mental level are characterized not only by the ability to adapt to the environment, but also by the ability to influence it to one degree or another, to remake it in accordance with their needs and goals.
Mistrust. As already noted, an important element of the situation of resistance is evaluation. The first thing that a person evaluates before any interaction is significance and safety. At the same time, if the expectation of the good is more significant than the feeling of danger, risky behavior arises (active resistance to circumstances, to the world). While in the case of preferring security to the desire to gain, the person avoids activity (hidden resistance).
However, first of all, all information is screened out on the basis of trust in it. Information may not be accepted by a person, despite the fact that it is true, if it causes distrust, and at the same time, a person can accept false information if it does not cause distrust in him. Thus, trust can be reduced to the absence of distrust.
Resistance will depend on the direction of distrust:
1. Distrust of the subject of influence. Such distrust implies interpersonal resistance, which can be based on intuition, negative interaction experience, etc. It can be expressed by anxiety, fear, aggressive behavior, etc.
2. Distrust of yourself. It is manifested by a refusal to change, development, a desire to leave even an unfavorable, dangerous state of affairs.
3. Distrust of information. It can be expressed by rational resistance (disagreement, bringing counterarguments), or irrational (misunderstanding, forgetting, ignoring).
4. Separately, one can single out information-normative distrust, which leads to sociological resistance to the norms of society and culture. Here, self-confidence and the expectation of personal benefit are strongly manifested. In contrast to this, there is resistance from society, which is aimed at preserving the usual norms and culture, refusing some benefits in favor of security.
Social. As we have already seen, a person constantly interacts with the social and enters into various social relations. At the same time, according to D. Brühl, by nature a person is a three-dimensional being, that is, he can be considered as a biological, psychological and spiritual being. What determines the nature of its interaction with the social. So, as a biological being, a person seeks to satisfy his needs, competing in this with other people. However, it should be understood that in a modern society built on the division of labor, human consumption depends on the production of goods by society. In addition, as a psychic being, a person is definitely social, he needs to communicate with other people, their respect and love. Also, based on his sociality, a person recognizes the rights to the existence of others, and that their dignity should be respected. As a spiritual being, a person has a need for solitude, searching for himself, realizing his potential. Therefore, a person needs some free space.
J. Burton in his works on conflict prevention and resolution emphasizes the importance of meeting human needs, while his hierarchy of needs reflects the three-dimensional nature of man. J. Beton modernized A. Maslow's theory of fundamental human needs. At the basis of his hierarchy lies the need for a fair distribution of wealth. The next step is the need for security. On the third - the need for belonging (love). The fourth stage Burton assigns the need for self-esteem, and the fifth - the need for self-realization. If the second, third, fourth and fifth levels of J. Burton's classification exactly coincide with the similar levels of A. Maslow's classification, the remaining four levels of the hierarchy are unique - the needs for identity, cultural security, freedom and complicity, respectively. J. Burton believed that the coordination of interests, the satisfaction of all basic needs is the basis of peaceful interaction.
It can be noted that in assessing the satisfaction of his needs, a person does not rely on some absolute values, his sense of fairness in the distribution of benefits will depend on his expectations and relative deprivation. Expectations significantly determine the essence and direction of human activity. Social expectations both influence the actions of people and social groups and reflect their worldview, value orientations and cognitive attitudes. If an individual or group expects a certain degree of satisfaction of their needs, but receives noticeably less, this will be assessed as injustice and will lead to an increase in discontent and even aggression. Relative deprivation is the perception that one is worse off than others or lacks the necessary resources compared to the reference group. This sense of deprivation arises from a sense of inconsistency between one's own situation and that of others who are perceived as similar or belonging to the same social group. Relative deprivation can lead to feelings of frustration, dissatisfaction and resentment. Reference groups are those social groups with which individuals compare themselves. The choice of a reference group is subjective and depends on the person's social identity, aspirations, and perceived similarities with group members. Comparison can be upward, when people see themselves as inferior or inferior, or downward, when they see themselves as better off or superior. The concept of reference groups helps explain why people often perceive relative deprivation even in situations where they have more than enough resources, since the comparison is based on subjective social standards rather than objective material conditions. Perceptions of inequality, discrimination, and unfair treatment stemming from social comparisons and feelings of deprivation can motivate individuals and groups to resist and challenge others, the prevailing social order, or structures.
Thus, having been exposed to some impact, assessing its degree of significance, safety, correlating it with his expectations, ideas, feelings, will, deciding to resist this impact, the subject clothes this decision in a certain form of behavior. In general, the form can be divided into external resistance and internal resistance. In turn, external resistance can be conditionally divided into physical resistance, verbal resistance and resistance-inaction. Physical resistance implies active resistance and can manifest itself in the form of fighting, hurting, and so on. Verbal resistance is often expressed in the form of disagreement, refusal, passive-aggressive comments, etc. Resistance-inaction can be expressed in the form of non-execution of orders, disobedience to orders, resistance to physical influence, avoidance of participation or cooperation, refusal to respond to requests or demonstration of lack of enthusiasm or interest, etc. Internal resistance is rational in nature and is expressed in unwillingness to do anything, suppression of emotions and thoughts, rejection, disagreement with oneself, emotional detachment. At the same time, implicit types of resistance can be tracked by non-verbal signs: body language, facial expressions and other non-verbal signals that can be used to express resistance or discomfort in interaction.

chosen.answer: In conclusion, the multifaceted nature of resistance, as explored across various scientific disciplines, underscores its significance in understanding human behavior and interaction with the environment. Resistance manifests not only as a response to external pressures but also as an internal psychological process influenced by individual personality traits, social dynamics, and contextual evaluations. The distinctions between external and internal forms of resistance highlight the complexity of human agency, where actions may range from overt physical confrontations to subtle non-verbal cues of discontent. Furthermore, the interplay of trust, expectations, and perceived inequalities shapes the motivations behind resistance, revealing how individuals navigate their social realities. Ultimately, this comprehensive examination of resistance emphasizes its role as a critical factor in personal and collective agency, reflecting the ongoing struggle for autonomy and self-determination in the face of various influences. As such, understanding resistance not only enriches our grasp of human behavior but also informs strategies for conflict resolution and social cohesion.

reject.answer:
In conclusion, the concept of resistance is a multifaceted and complex phenomenon that has been studied in various scientific disciplines, including physics, biology, sociology, psychology, and ecology. Resistance can be defined as the ability of an object or individual to withstand or counteract the impact of external forces, influences, or pressures. In the context of human behavior, resistance can take many forms, including physical, verbal, intellectual, and emotional actions.

The essence of resistance can be understood through the concept of social action, which involves the purposeful transformation of the outside world by individuals or groups. Resistance can be seen as a form of social action that is motivated by a desire to maintain a sense of control, autonomy, and self-expression in the face of external pressures or threats.

The study of resistance also highlights the importance of trust and expectations in shaping human behavior. Distrust can lead to resistance, and people may resist information, ideas, or norms that they do not trust or that contradict their existing beliefs and values. Expectations, on the other hand, can influence how individuals evaluate situations and determine their course of action.

Finally, the concept of reference groups is important in understanding resistance, as individuals often compare themselves to others in their social group and perceive relative deprivation or inequality, leading to feelings of frustration and motivation to resist. The forms of resistance can vary, including external resistance, such as physical or verbal resistance, and internal resistance, such as rational or emotional resistance.

Overall, the concept of resistance is a crucial aspect of human behavior that is shaped by a complex interplay of factors, including social norms, expectations, trust, and personal values. Understanding resistance is essential in various fields, including psychology, sociology, and politics, as it can help us better comprehend human behavior and develop strategies to address conflicts and promote positive change.

First of all, the study of resistance in order to identify its essential parameters implies an appeal to its most characteristic formulations. And since resistance is a significant element in many areas of human life, there are a number of scientific disciplines in which the phenomenon of "resistance" is studied. Among them are physics, history, biology, medicine, psychology and others. However, each science views resistance from a unique position and perspective. So in physics, resistance is “a property, ability (of materials, structures, etc.) to resist any influences, changes.” In financial science, resistance is “a price market situation in which there is a tendency for new sales in order to slow down the continued rise in prices.” In sociology, resistance is "resistance, opposition". In ecology, resistance is defined as "the resistance of an organism (population, biocenosis) to the effects of various factors (for example, poisons, pollutants, parasites, diseases)" . In psychoanalysis, resistance is “the forces and processes that prevent the awareness of information by counteracting the transition of memories, ideas and symptoms from the unconscious to consciousness” . And in psychology, resistance is considered, among other things, as a personality trait, unwillingness to follow orders, “a reaction to group pressure, etc.”
Each given scientific representation of resistance contributes to the general understanding of the phenomenon. While not all of the areas of science discussed above are relevant to the study of human nature, they reflect various aspects of human life and its interaction with environmental conditions, including physical, social, biological, physiological and psychological factors. However, in all scientific approaches related to resistance, there is a general concept of the ability of an object to withstand and / or counteract the impact. This idea is most widely developed by A. Reber, who defines resistance as “any action of the body that is directed against some kind of force, rebuffs it, fights against it, opposes it” .
In this work, the focus is on resistance as applied to a person, starting with a more general understanding, gradually moving to a conflictological paradigm.
From the previous definitions, it is clear that the phenomenon of resistance is a complex, multifaceted and multiformat activity that can be accompanied by both physical and verbal, intellectual and emotional actions. At the same time, the concept of "action" can also mean "non-action", refusal or refraining from action. Activity is a typical human form of active interaction with the outside world, the main essence of which is the purposeful transformation and transformation of this world. This process involves a certain confrontation between the subject and object of this activity. The theory of social action, reflected in the works of M. Weber, F. Znaniecki and T. Parsons, highlights the role of value attitudes, activity motives, orientation, expectations, as well as other factors important for goal-setting and implementation of activities, along with an analysis of the rational components of goal-setting activity . The concept of social action was introduced into scientific circulation by the sociologist Max Weber. According to M. Weber, social action includes a combination of the subjective motivation of an individual or group and the orientation of this individual / group to the behavior of other people (groups) in the past, present or future.
Thus, resistance can be divided into its subject and object, where the subject of resistance is a resisting person (group), and the object is the impact directed at the subject, causing resistance. As with any activity, resistance is characterized by purposefulness. Let's consider this in more detail. In a situation of resistance, two events take place, logically connected by causal relationships. The reason is "a phenomenon that directly causes, generates another phenomenon (consequence)." Then for resistance, the cause will be an event-impact, and the effect will be an event-resistance. At the same time, the concept of cause is rooted in the past, the goal is focused on the future, while the motive of human activity can be both in the past and in the future. Schematically, the situation of resistance can be formulated as follows: there is some event (an object of resistance) that affects the subject (a person, a group of people, society, etc.) in a certain way; the subject evaluates the event as unfavorable for himself and resists its impact, as he has the goal of preventing the development of the situation in an unfavorable direction for himself. Thus, two more essential elements of the situation of resistance can be distinguished: the subject's assessment of the object of resistance (negative), as well as the goal of the subject of resistance. Next, we will consider how such an assessment and goal-setting takes place.
Personality. The formation of personality is associated with the presence of long-term goals and an ideal image of oneself. The values of each individual depend on the goals that he perceives as positively significant in accordance with the norms accepted in society, personal experience and individual preferences. Personality implies a set of stable motives that underlie the orientation of the subject in the social environment and his assessments of situations. The person's ability to be flexible and at the same time resist the pressure of the environment will depend on the type of personality. A.F. Lazursky distinguishes three mental levels of personality - the lowest, the middle and the highest. People with a lower mental level practically do not resist the social environment, obey it, they do not differ in an independent attitude and are not capable of self-realization. With an average mental level, people adapt to the environment, find their place in it and are able to use it to achieve their goals. Such people are distinguished by flexibility of mind, high awareness, purposefulness, initiative, and a good understanding of themselves. People with a high mental level are characterized not only by the ability to adapt to the environment, but also by the ability to influence it to one degree or another, to remake it in accordance with their needs and goals.
Mistrust. As already noted, an important element of the situation of resistance is evaluation. The first thing that a person evaluates before any interaction is significance and safety. At the same time, if the expectation of the good is more significant than the feeling of danger, risky behavior arises (active resistance to circumstances, to the world). While in the case of preferring security to the desire to gain, the person avoids activity (hidden resistance).
However, first of all, all information is screened out on the basis of trust in it. Information may not be accepted by a person, despite the fact that it is true, if it causes distrust, and at the same time, a person can accept false information if it does not cause distrust in him. Thus, trust can be reduced to the absence of distrust.
Resistance will depend on the direction of distrust:
1. Distrust of the subject of influence. Such distrust implies interpersonal resistance, which can be based on intuition, negative interaction experience, etc. It can be expressed by anxiety, fear, aggressive behavior, etc.
2. Distrust of yourself. It is manifested by a refusal to change, development, a desire to leave even an unfavorable, dangerous state of affairs.
3. Distrust of information. It can be expressed by rational resistance (disagreement, bringing counterarguments), or irrational (misunderstanding, forgetting, ignoring).
4. Separately, one can single out information-normative distrust, which leads to sociological resistance to the norms of society and culture. Here, self-confidence and the expectation of personal benefit are strongly manifested. In contrast to this, there is resistance from society, which is aimed at preserving the usual norms and culture, refusing some benefits in favor of security.
Social. As we have already seen, a person constantly interacts with the social and enters into various social relations. At the same time, according to D. Brühl, by nature a person is a three-dimensional being, that is, he can be considered as a biological, psychological and spiritual being. What determines the nature of its interaction with the social. So, as a biological being, a person seeks to satisfy his needs, competing in this with other people. However, it should be understood that in a modern society built on the division of labor, human consumption depends on the production of goods by society. In addition, as a psychic being, a person is definitely social, he needs to communicate with other people, their respect and love. Also, based on his sociality, a person recognizes the rights to the existence of others, and that their dignity should be respected. As a spiritual being, a person has a need for solitude, searching for himself, realizing his potential. Therefore, a person needs some free space.
J. Burton in his works on conflict prevention and resolution emphasizes the importance of meeting human needs, while his hierarchy of needs reflects the three-dimensional nature of man. J. Beton modernized A. Maslow's theory of fundamental human needs. At the basis of his hierarchy lies the need for a fair distribution of wealth. The next step is the need for security. On the third - the need for belonging (love). The fourth stage Burton assigns the need for self-esteem, and the fifth - the need for self-realization. If the second, third, fourth and fifth levels of J. Burton's classification exactly coincide with the similar levels of A. Maslow's classification, the remaining four levels of the hierarchy are unique - the needs for identity, cultural security, freedom and complicity, respectively. J. Burton believed that the coordination of interests, the satisfaction of all basic needs is the basis of peaceful interaction.
It can be noted that in assessing the satisfaction of his needs, a person does not rely on some absolute values, his sense of fairness in the distribution of benefits will depend on his expectations and relative deprivation. Expectations significantly determine the essence and direction of human activity. Social expectations both influence the actions of people and social groups and reflect their worldview, value orientations and cognitive attitudes. If an individual or group expects a certain degree of satisfaction of their needs, but receives noticeably less, this will be assessed as injustice and will lead to an increase in discontent and even aggression. Relative deprivation is the perception that one is worse off than others or lacks the necessary resources compared to the reference group. This sense of deprivation arises from a sense of inconsistency between one's own situation and that of others who are perceived as similar or belonging to the same social group. Relative deprivation can lead to feelings of frustration, dissatisfaction and resentment. Reference groups are those social groups with which individuals compare themselves. The choice of a reference group is subjective and depends on the person's social identity, aspirations, and perceived similarities with group members. Comparison can be upward, when people see themselves as inferior or inferior, or downward, when they see themselves as better off or superior. The concept of reference groups helps explain why people often perceive relative deprivation even in situations where they have more than enough resources, since the comparison is based on subjective social standards rather than objective material conditions. Perceptions of inequality, discrimination, and unfair treatment stemming from social comparisons and feelings of deprivation can motivate individuals and groups to resist and challenge others, the prevailing social order, or structures.
Thus, having been exposed to some impact, assessing its degree of significance, safety, correlating it with his expectations, ideas, feelings, will, deciding to resist this impact, the subject clothes this decision in a certain form of behavior. In general, the form can be divided into external resistance and internal resistance. In turn, external resistance can be conditionally divided into physical resistance, verbal resistance and resistance-inaction. Physical resistance implies active resistance and can manifest itself in the form of fighting, hurting, and so on. Verbal resistance is often expressed in the form of disagreement, refusal, passive-aggressive comments, etc. Resistance-inaction can be expressed in the form of non-execution of orders, disobedience to orders, resistance to physical influence, avoidance of participation or cooperation, refusal to respond to requests or demonstration of lack of enthusiasm or interest, etc. Internal resistance is rational in nature and is expressed in unwillingness to do anything, suppression of emotions and thoughts, rejection, disagreement with oneself, emotional detachment. At the same time, implicit types of resistance can be tracked by non-verbal signs: body language, facial expressions and other non-verbal signals that can be used to express resistance or discomfort in interaction.

The multifaceted concept of resistance encompasses the ability of an object to withstand and countervail the effects of external stimuli. Resistance is a complex and multidimensional activity that can manifest in various forms, including physical, verbal, intellectual, and emotional actions or non-actions. By understanding the essence and parameters of resistance, we can better comprehend the complex dynamics of human interaction and the factors that influence resistance in various contexts.

bard ai vs chatgpt
BARD AI VS CHATGPT: THE ULTIMATE AI SHOWDOWN
MATT·MAY 11, 2023
AI
CHATGPT
NEWS
5 MINS READ
In the ever-evolving world of artificial intelligence (AI), two giants have emerged at the forefront: Bard AI from Google and ChatGPT from OpenAI. With advancements in machine learning algorithms, natural language processing capabilities, and state-of-the-art models, these two AI chatbots have become major players in the industry. But which is superior? Let’s dive into the differences, strengths, and weaknesses of each to find out.

THE GIANTS OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE: BARD AI AND CHATGPT
ChatGPT Prompt Pack
Bard AI and ChatGPT represent cutting-edge developments in AI technology. They’re both powerful tools that can comprehend and generate human-like text, but they also have unique characteristics that set them apart.

UNRAVELING THE MYSTIQUE OF BARD AI
Google’s Bard AI is a sophisticated machine learning model that has been trained on an extensive variety of data sources. This AI is no slouch when it comes to understanding context, making relevant responses, and even demonstrating a sense of humor.

UNDERSTANDING THE CAPABILITIES OF CHATGPT
ChatGPT, on the other hand, is OpenAI’s flagship AI model. Known for its versatility and impressive language understanding abilities, ChatGPT can engage in detailed discussions, write essays, and even offer insights on complex topics.

THE CLASH: IS GOOGLE BARD BETTER THAN CHATGPT?
When it comes to the question of whether Google Bard is better than ChatGPT, the answer isn’t quite cut-and-dried. They both excel in different areas, making it more of a matter of preference rather than a clear win.

BARD AI’S STRENGTHS
Bard AI shines in its ability to understand and generate natural language. It’s particularly good at creating content that’s not just grammatically accurate but also contextually relevant. Its responses are often detailed and nuanced, suggesting a deep understanding of the subject matter.

CHATGPT’S EDGE
ChatGPT, while also excelling in natural language understanding and generation, has a different advantage. It’s incredibly versatile, able to switch between different writing styles and tones effortlessly. Whether you need a detailed technical explanation or a casual chat, ChatGPT can deliver.

WHICH AI IS BETTER THAN CHATGPT?
In the current landscape of AI technology, it’s tough to find an AI that outperforms ChatGPT. Its ability to generate human-like text that’s contextually relevant and highly detailed is truly a marvel of AI engineering. While Bard AI is a worthy competitor, it’s not definitively better, only different.

THE DISTINCT DIFFERENCES BETWEEN BARD AND CHATGPT
The differences between Bard and ChatGPT lie primarily in their training data, algorithms, and overall objectives.

BARD AI’S UNIQUE FEATURES
ChatGPT Prompt Pack
Bard AI has been trained on a wide range of datasets, making it highly adaptable to different contexts. It’s also been engineered to have a sense of humor, which can make its responses feel more human-like.

CHATGPT’S DISTINGUISHING FACTORS
ChatGPT, on the other hand, has been designed to be highly versatile, capable of handling a wide range of tasks. From generating text to answering questions and holding conversations, ChatGPT can do it all.

THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN AI CHAT AND CHATGPT
While AI chat and ChatGPT might seem similar, they’re not identical. AI chat generally refers to any AI model that can engage in conversation, while ChatGPT is a specific instance of an AI chat model, developed by OpenAI, with its own unique features and capabilities.

THE POTENTIAL OF BARD AI
Bard AI is undeniably impressive. Its ability to understand context, generate detailed responses, and even show a sense of humor sets it apart from many other AI models. It’s the result of Google’s efforts to push the boundaries of what AI can achieve, and its potential is immense. As with all AI, Bard’s capabilities will continue to evolve with ongoing development and training.

IS CHATGPT THE MOST ADVANCED AI?
ChatGPT is undeniably one of the most advanced AI models available today. Its versatility and deep understanding of language make it an incredibly powerful tool. However, the field of AI is rapidly advancing, and numerous models are pushing the boundaries of what’s possible. While ChatGPT is a leader today, the landscape of AI is constantly changing.

THE FUTURE OF AI: BARD AI AND CHATGPT
While it’s difficult to predict exactly where the future of AI is headed, it’s clear that both Bard AI and ChatGPT will continue to play significant roles. Their ability to understand and generate human-like text opens up a world of possibilities, from improving customer service interactions to enhancing our ability to analyze and understand complex data.

ChatGPT Prompt Pack
Bard AI and ChatGPT, while distinct in their capabilities, represent the pinnacle of AI development as of now. As these technologies continue to advance, we can expect to see even more impressive feats of artificial intelligence in the years to come.

CONCLUSION
In the end, whether Bard AI or ChatGPT is “better” largely depends on the specific requirements at hand. Both AI models offer unique strengths: Bard’s humor and detailed responses, and ChatGPT’s versatility and adaptability. However, the future of AI is not a zero-sum game. Instead, the continued development of these AI models promises to push the boundaries of what’s possible, to the benefit of us all.

FAQS
1. Is Google’s Bard AI more advanced than OpenAI’s ChatGPT? While Bard AI and ChatGPT both represent significant advancements in AI, it’s difficult to definitively say which is more advanced. They each have their strengths and are impressive in their own right.

2. Can Bard AI and ChatGPT understand and respond to any text input? While Bard AI and ChatGPT are highly sophisticated, they do have limitations. They’re best at responding to clear, concise text inputs and may struggle with highly ambiguous or nonsensical inputs.

3. Is Bard AI better at generating text than ChatGPT? Bard AI and ChatGPT are both highly capable text generators. Bard AI is known for its contextually relevant and detailed responses, while ChatGPT is praised for its versatility and adaptability.

4. Can I use Bard AI and ChatGPT for any type of text generation task? While both AI models are highly versatile, they’re not suitable for every task. They’re most effective when used for tasks that align with their training data and objectives.

5. How will Bard AI and ChatGPT evolve in the future? Both AI models will continue to evolve as developers refine their algorithms and train them on more and more data. We can expect to see continual improvements in their language understanding and generation capabilities.

## Summary: Bard AI vs ChatGPT

This article compares Google's Bard AI and OpenAI's ChatGPT, two leading AI chatbots.  The author concludes that while both are powerful tools with different strengths, neither is definitively "better" than the other. The choice depends on the specific needs of the user.

## Important Information:

* **Bard AI (Google):**
    * Strengths: Excellent natural language understanding, contextually relevant responses, detailed and nuanced content generation, sense of humor.
    * Trained on a wide variety of data sets.
    * Focuses on natural and engaging conversation.

* **ChatGPT (OpenAI):**
    * Strengths: Versatility, adaptability to different writing styles and tones, capable of handling a wide range of tasks (e.g., essays, detailed explanations, conversations).
    * Considered one of the most advanced AI models currently available.
    * Excels in generating human-like text that's contextually relevant and highly detailed.

* **Key Differences:**
    * Training data and algorithms.
    * Bard AI leans towards more natural and engaging conversation with a touch of humor.
    * ChatGPT prioritizes versatility and adaptability for various tasks.

* **Conclusion:**
    * Both are powerful and impressive AI models.
    * Choosing between them depends on the specific task and desired output.
    * Both will likely continue to play significant roles in the future of AI.

* **Future of AI:**
    * Both Bard AI and ChatGPT are expected to continue evolving and improving.
    * This continuous development will likely lead to even more impressive AI capabilities in the future.

ChatGPT Prompt Pack

UNRAVELING THE MYSTIQUE OF BARD AI
Google’s Bard AI is a sophisticated machine learning model that has been trained on an extensive variety of data sources. This AI is no slouch when it comes to understanding context, making relevant responses, and even demonstrating a sense of humor.

UNDERSTANDING THE CAPABILITIES OF CHATGPT
ChatGPT, on the other hand, is OpenAI’s flagship AI model. Known for its versatility and impressive language understanding abilities, ChatGPT can engage in detailed discussions, write essays, and even offer insights on complex topics.

THE CLASH: IS GOOGLE BARD BETTER THAN CHATGPT?
When it comes to the question of whether Google Bard is better than ChatGPT, the answer isn’t quite cut-and-dried. They both excel in different areas, making it more of a matter of preference rather than a clear win.

BARD AI’S STRENGTHS
Bard AI shines in its ability to understand and generate natural language. It’s particularly good at creating content that’s not just grammatically accurate but also contextually relevant. Its responses are often detailed and nuanced, suggesting a deep understanding of the subject matter.

CHATGPT’S EDGE
ChatGPT, while also excelling in natural language understanding and generation, has a different advantage. It’s incredibly versatile, able to switch between different writing styles and tones effortlessly. Whether you need a detailed technical explanation or a casual chat, ChatGPT can deliver.

WHICH AI IS BETTER THAN CHATGPT?
In the current landscape of AI technology, it’s tough to find an AI that outperforms ChatGPT. Its ability to generate human-like text that’s contextually relevant and highly detailed is truly a marvel of AI engineering. While Bard AI is a worthy competitor, it’s not definitively better, only different.

The differences between Bard and ChatGPT lie primarily in their training data, algorithms, and overall objectives.

Bard AI has been trained on a wide range of datasets, making it highly adaptable to different contexts. It’s also been engineered to have a sense of humor, which can make its responses feel more human-like.

CHATGPT’S DISTINGUISHING FACTORS
ChatGPT, on the other hand, has been designed to be highly versatile, capable of handling a wide range of tasks. From generating text to answering questions and holding conversations, ChatGPT can do it all.

THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN AI CHAT AND CHATGPT
While AI chat and ChatGPT might seem similar, they’re not identical. AI chat generally refers to any AI model that can engage in conversation, while ChatGPT is a specific instance of an AI chat model, developed by OpenAI, with its own unique features and capabilities.

THE POTENTIAL OF BARD AI
Bard AI is undeniably impressive. Its ability to understand context, generate detailed responses, and even show a sense of humor sets it apart from many other AI models. It’s the result of Google’s efforts to push the boundaries of what AI can achieve, and its potential is immense. As with all AI, Bard’s capabilities will continue to evolve with ongoing development and training.

IS CHATGPT THE MOST ADVANCED AI?
ChatGPT is undeniably one of the most advanced AI models available today. Its versatility and deep understanding of language make it an incredibly powerful tool. However, the field of AI is rapidly advancing, and numerous models are pushing the boundaries of what’s possible. While ChatGPT is a leader today, the landscape of AI is constantly changing.

THE FUTURE OF AI: BARD AI AND CHATGPT
While it’s difficult to predict exactly where the future of AI is headed, it’s clear that both Bard AI and ChatGPT will continue to play significant roles. Their ability to understand and generate human-like text opens up a world of possibilities, from improving customer service interactions to enhancing our ability to analyze and understand complex data.

ChatGPT Prompt Pack
Bard AI and ChatGPT, while distinct in their capabilities, represent the pinnacle of AI development as of now. As these technologies continue to advance, we can expect to see even more impressive feats of artificial intelligence in the years to come.

In the end, whether Bard AI or ChatGPT is “better” largely depends on the specific requirements at hand. Both AI models offer unique strengths: Bard’s humor and detailed responses, and ChatGPT’s versatility and adaptability. However, the future of AI is not a zero-sum game. Instead, the continued development of these AI models promises to push the boundaries of what’s possible, to the benefit of us all.

    * Focuses on natural and engaging conversation.

    * Strengths: Versatility, adaptability to different writing styles and tones, capable of handling a wide range of tasks (e.g., essays, detailed explanations, conversations).

    * Training data and algorithms.
    * Bard AI leans towards more natural and engaging conversation with a touch of humor.
    * ChatGPT prioritizes versatility and adaptability for various tasks.

* **Conclusion:**
    * Both are powerful and impressive AI models.
    * Choosing between them depends on the specific task and desired output.
    * Both will likely continue to play significant roles in the future of AI.

* **Future of AI:**
    * Both Bard AI and ChatGPT are expected to continue evolving and improving.
    * This continuous development will likely lead to even more impressive AI capabilities in the future.

sabrina-ortiz
Written by Sabrina Ortiz, Associate Editor on May 12, 2023
Stability AI Animation SDK
Screenshot by Sabrina Ortiz/ZDNET
From anime to childhood classics, animations have brought stories to life by combining still images. Now, with just a text prompt, you can generate your own animations using AI.

On Thursday, Stability AI, the AI company that created Stable Diffusion, unveiled a text-to-animation tool that allows developers and artists to use Stable Diffusion models to generate animations. 

Also: The best AI art generators: DALL-E 2 and other fun alternatives to try

The tool, known as Stable Animation SDK, can generate video from three different inputs including text alone, text and an initial image, and text and an input video.

ZDNET Tech Today - US

subscribe

— datajules (@j_vicente_go) May 12, 2023

The cost of an operation is based on a credit system and varies depending on the video dimensions and 3D render mode. The cost ranges from 0.058 to 0.174 credits per operation.

For full details on how to use Stable Animation SDK and the cost involved, visit Stability AI's developer platform for Animation SDK.

conversation_input.content: summarize "The gift of imperfection" book using the Pareto principle

"The Gift of Imperfection" is centered on embracing your authentic self and cultivating worthiness by letting go of the need for perfection. Utilizing the Pareto Principle, which states that 80% of results come from 20% of efforts, the primary takeaway from the book is to focus on self-compassion, vulnerability, and resilience. By doing so, we can develop meaningful connections with others and live wholeheartedly, ultimately leading to a more fulfilling life.
summarize the main ideas of “The gift of imperfection” book

chosen.answer:
**Main Ideas of "The Gift of Imperfection"**

* **Embrace Your Imperfections:** Recognize that perfection is an unattainable and unhealthy goal. Allow yourself to be human and make mistakes.
* **Practice Self-Compassion:** Treat yourself with the same kindness and understanding you would offer a friend. Forgive your mistakes and focus on your strengths.
* **Let Go of Comparison:** Stop comparing yourself to others. Everyone has their own unique path and timeline. Celebrate your own journey.
* **Cultivate Gratitude:** Practice gratitude for the good things in your life, both big and small. This helps shift your focus from what's lacking to what's present.
* **Set Boundaries:** Protect your time and energy by setting boundaries with others. Learn to say no to commitments that don't align with your values.
* **Be Vulnerable:** Share your authentic self with others, even if it means showing your weaknesses. Vulnerability fosters connection and builds trust.
* **Live Wholeheartedly:** Engage fully in life, embracing both the joys and challenges. Let go of perfectionism and strive for a life filled with purpose and meaning.

**Core Message:**

True worthiness comes from accepting and loving yourself unconditionally, flaws and all. By embracing our imperfections, we create space for authenticity, connection, and a more fulfilling life.

reject.answer:
Here is a summary of the main ideas from the book "The Gift of Imperfection" by Brené Brown:

- Wholehearted Living: The book encourages embracing vulnerability, imperfection, and living a "wholehearted" life where you fully engage with your emotions and experiences without numbing or distancing yourself. 

- Cultivating Self-Worth: Brown discusses how comparing ourselves to others and pursuing perfection actually undermine our self-worth. She advocates cultivating worthiness from within by embracing our vulnerabilities.

- Shame Resilience: The book examines how shame impacts people and provides strategies for developing "shame resilience" or the ability to acknowledge and learn from mistakes without being defined by them. 

- Authenticity: A major theme is living authentically by accepting ourselves as "enough" and not basing our self-worth on others' opinions or unrealistic standards of perfection. 

- Connection Through Vulnerability: Brown argues that true belonging and connection with others can only happen when we allow ourselves to be imperfect and vulnerable through stories and emotions we share.

- Letting Go of "Should": Releasing the need to meet culturally-imposed shoulds/expectations and prioritizing our own values and definition of well-being.

So in summary, the book promotes embracing imperfections, cultivating self-worth from within, developing shame resilience, living authentically, connecting through vulnerability, and letting go of unrealistic "shoulds."

2. **Cultivating Worthiness**: Brown argues that worthiness is a fundamental belief that we are enough as we are. This belief is crucial for developing self-esteem and resilience.

3. **Vulnerability**: Embracing vulnerability is key to forming genuine connections with others. It involves being open and honest about our struggles and fears.

4. **Shame and Fear**: The book discusses how shame can hinder our ability to connect with others and live authentically. Brown provides strategies for overcoming shame and fostering a sense of belonging.

5. **Wholehearted Living**: Brown introduces the concept of "wholehearted living," which involves engaging in life from a place of worthiness, courage, and compassion. It encourages individuals to live authentically and embrace their true selves.

6. **Self-Compassion**: Practicing self-compassion is vital for overcoming negative self-talk and fostering a positive self-image. It involves treating ourselves with kindness and understanding, especially during difficult times.

7. **Connection and Community**: Building meaningful relationships is essential for emotional well-being. The book emphasizes the importance of vulnerability in creating deep connections with others.

Overall, "The Gift of Imperfection" advocates for a shift in mindset from perfectionism to authenticity, encouraging readers to embrace their true selves and live with courage and compassion.

"The Gift of Imperfection" by Brené Brown is centered on the idea that embracing our imperfections and vulnerabilities is the key to living a more authentic, fulfilling, and wholehearted life. The book's main ideas can be summarized as follows:

1. Perfectionism is not the same as self-worth: Brown argues that many people believe that self-worth is tied to their ability to be perfect, but this is a flawed belief. Self-worth comes from being imperfect and embracing those imperfections.
2. Imperfections are a strength, not a weakness: Brown challenges the cultural belief that imperfections are something to be ashamed of or hidden. Instead, she argues that imperfections are a natural and necessary part of being human.
3. Vulnerability is a strength: Brown defines vulnerability as the willingness to be imperfect and to take risks. She argues that vulnerability is a strength, not a weakness, and that it is essential for building meaningful connections with others.
4. Shame and guilt are barriers to living a wholehearted life: Brown explains that shame and guilt are toxic emotions that can prevent us from living a wholehearted life. She argues that we must learn to acknowledge and let go of these emotions in order to live authentically.
5. Cultivating self-compassion is essential: Brown emphasizes the importance of treating ourselves with kindness, understanding, and acceptance, rather than criticism and judgment. She argues that self-compassion is essential for building resilience and living a wholehearted life.
6. Wholehearted living requires courage, gratitude, and authenticity: Brown identifies three key components of wholehearted living: courage (the willingness to be vulnerable and take risks), gratitude (the ability to acknowledge and appreciate what we have), and authenticity (the willingness to be ourselves, imperfections and all).
7. Embracing imperfections is a muscle that can be developed: Brown argues that like any other skill, the ability to embrace imperfections is something that can be developed through practice and effort.
8. Cultivating a sense of belonging is essential for living a wholehearted life: Brown argues that a sense of belonging is essential for living a wholehearted life. She explains that this means connecting with others, being part of a community, and feeling a sense of belonging to something larger than ourselves.

Overall, "The Gift of Imperfection" is a powerful call to action to embrace our imperfections and live a more authentic, fulfilling, and wholehearted life. By challenging cultural beliefs about perfectionism and vulnerability, and offering practical strategies for cultivating self-compassion and resilience, Brown provides readers with a framework for living a more meaningful and connected life.

reject.answer: "The Gift of Imperfection" emphasizes the importance of self-compassion, vulnerability, and resilience in cultivating worthiness and living wholeheartedly. The book encourages readers to embrace their authentic self and let go of the need for perfection, as this can hinders personal growth and happiness. By accepting our imperfections and flaws, we can develop meaningful connections with others and live our lives with authenticity and purpose. The book also highlights the power of mindfulness and the importance of embracing our own emotions and experiences, rather than avoiding or suppressing them. Ultimately, the main idea of the book is that imperfection is a natural part of the human experience and that we can all learn to embrace it in order to cultivate a more joyful and fulfilling life.

Neeva, the would-be Google competitor, is shutting down its search engine / “We’ve discovered that it is one thing to build a search engine, and an entirely different thing to convince regular users of the need to switch to a better choice.”
By David Pierce, editor-at-large and Vergecast co-host with over a decade of experience covering consumer tech. Previously, at Protocol, The Wall Street Journal, and Wired.

May 20, 2023, 9:58 PM UTC
Share this story



An illustration of the Neeva browser running on a mobile phone.
Neeva tried to build a different kind of search engine — but couldn’t make the business work. Image: Neeva
Neeva, which for a while looked like one of the startups with a real chance to challenge the supremacy of Google Search, announced on Saturday that it is shutting down its search engine. The company says it’s pivoting to AI — and may be acquired by Snowflake, The Information reported — but mostly seems to believe it failed.

“Building search engines is hard,” Neeva co-founders Sridhar Ramaswamy and Vivek Raghunathan wrote in a blog post announcing the shutdown. (Ramaswamy in particular is part of the reason Neeva seemed promising — as the longtime head of Google’s ad business, few people are better equipped to know how to build and monetize search than he is.) But Neeva did it, they said. It built a good, competitive search engine. It was actually well ahead of Google in some respects, like swapping 10 blue links for a more visual page and emphasizing human-created information.

But building the search engine was actually the easy part. “Throughout this journey, we’ve discovered that it is one thing to build a search engine, and an entirely different thing to convince regular users of the need to switch to a better choice,” Ramaswamy and Raghunathan continued.

Building the search engine was actually the easy part

I’ve talked with Neeva’s co-founders several times over the last couple of years, and their list of grievances here is long and well-founded. They’ve had to contend with the billion-dollar deals Google signs to make itself the default search engine on devices everywhere; the huge “are you sure you want to change?” popups that show up whenever you try to set a new default browser or search engine; the difficulty of finding those settings in the first place; the mess that is the Chrome Web Store; on and on and on. Anyone trying to build a new search engine is fighting a massively uphill battle.

Neeva was also a paid product, as the company tried to prove a business model for search other than ads and surveillance. “Contrary to popular belief,” the co-founders wrote in the blog post, “convincing users to pay for a better experience was actually a less difficult problem compared to getting them to try a new search engine in the first place.” Combine that with a tough economy, and Neeva simply couldn’t see a business path forward.

The timing here is really interesting. Neeva is shutting down at what might be the best moment in two decades for upstart search engines. Users are increasingly fed up with the ad load and subpar results they get from Google, and AI chatbots like Bing and ChatGPT have upended everyone’s idea about how to interact with the internet. Neeva bet on this, too, developing a large language model-based system called Neeva AI that is in many ways more useful than what you’ll get from Bing or Bard. But that wasn’t enough either.

The race to take down Google is still very much on, of course: Bing continues to push hard to gain market share, and Brave recently touted that it now runs completely on its own search stack. Companies like you.com and DuckDuckGo are also trying to re-think the way search works, and using AI to do so. But so far, it looks like Google’s only real competitor is, well, Google.

Neeva’s search engine will shut down on June 2. Going forward, Neeva will be “shifting to a new area of focus,” which seems likely to be LLM-based and related to the Snowflake acquisition. The company will be refunding users for the unused portion of their Neeva subscriptions, and deleting all user data. “We are truly grateful to our community,” the co-founders wrote, “and we are truly sorry that we aren’t able to continue to provide the search engine that you want and deserve.”

## Summary:

Neeva, a search engine aiming to challenge Google's dominance, is shutting down its search engine and pivoting to AI.  Despite building a well-regarded search engine with innovative features, Neeva struggled to overcome the hurdles of convincing users to switch from Google, monetizing a paid search product, and navigating a challenging economic climate.


## Important Information:

* **Neeva shutting down:** Neeva's search engine is shutting down on June 2nd, 2023.
* **Reason for shutdown:**  Despite a quality product, Neeva failed to gain enough users to be viable. The company cites the difficulty of convincing users to switch from Google, the challenges of a subscription-based model, and the current economic climate.
* **Pivoting to AI:** Neeva is shifting its focus to AI and may be acquired by Snowflake.
* **Founder's background:** Neeva was co-founded by Sridhar Ramaswamy, former head of Google's ad business.
* **Neeva's innovations:** Neeva offered a more visual search experience, emphasized human-created information, and was ad-free with a paid subscription model.
* **Challenges for search engine startups:** The article highlights the difficulties faced by any company trying to compete with Google, including default search engine deals, difficult-to-change settings, and the dominance of the Chrome Web Store.
* **Refunds and data deletion:** Neeva will refund users for the unused portion of their subscriptions and delete all user data.
* **The future of search:** The article mentions other companies like Bing, Brave, you.com, and DuckDuckGo who are also trying to challenge Google's dominance in search.


This summarizes the key information from the article and provides important bullet points for quick reference.

reject.answer:
### Summary of Neeva's Shutdown

Neeva, a startup that aimed to compete with Google Search, has announced it will shut down its search engine on June 2, 2023. The company plans to pivot towards AI technology and may be acquired by Snowflake. Despite building a competitive search engine, Neeva struggled to attract users away from Google, which has a stronghold on the market due to various challenges, including default settings and user habits. The co-founders acknowledged that while creating the search engine was feasible, convincing users to switch proved to be a significant hurdle.

### Important Information

- **Shutdown Announcement**: Neeva will shut down its search engine on June 2, 2023.
- **Future Focus**: The company is pivoting to AI and may be acquired by Snowflake.
- **Co-founders**: Sridhar Ramaswamy and Vivek Raghunathan led the company.
- **Competitive Edge**: Neeva's search engine was noted for being visually different and emphasizing human-created content.
- **Challenges Faced**:
  - Difficulty in convincing users to switch from Google.
  - Competing against Google's default search engine deals and user interface barriers.
  - Neeva operated as a paid service, which was less challenging than getting users to try it.
- **Market Context**: The shutdown comes at a time when users are dissatisfied with Google’s ad-heavy search results, and AI chatbots are changing search dynamics.
- **Refunds and Data Deletion**: Neeva will refund users for unused subscriptions and delete all user data.
- **Acknowledgment**: The co-founders expressed gratitude to their community and regret over the shutdown.

conversation_input.content:
Summarize this and list important information as bullet points: Skip to main content
The Verge homepage

Menu

Menu
WEB/TECH/APPS
Neeva, the would-be Google competitor, is shutting down its search engine / “We’ve discovered that it is one thing to build a search engine, and an entirely different thing to convince regular users of the need to switch to a better choice.”
By David Pierce, editor-at-large and Vergecast co-host with over a decade of experience covering consumer tech. Previously, at Protocol, The Wall Street Journal, and Wired.

May 20, 2023, 9:58 PM UTC
Share this story



An illustration of the Neeva browser running on a mobile phone.
Neeva tried to build a different kind of search engine — but couldn’t make the business work. Image: Neeva
Neeva, which for a while looked like one of the startups with a real chance to challenge the supremacy of Google Search, announced on Saturday that it is shutting down its search engine. The company says it’s pivoting to AI — and may be acquired by Snowflake, The Information reported — but mostly seems to believe it failed.

“Building search engines is hard,” Neeva co-founders Sridhar Ramaswamy and Vivek Raghunathan wrote in a blog post announcing the shutdown. (Ramaswamy in particular is part of the reason Neeva seemed promising — as the longtime head of Google’s ad business, few people are better equipped to know how to build and monetize search than he is.) But Neeva did it, they said. It built a good, competitive search engine. It was actually well ahead of Google in some respects, like swapping 10 blue links for a more visual page and emphasizing human-created information.

But building the search engine was actually the easy part. “Throughout this journey, we’ve discovered that it is one thing to build a search engine, and an entirely different thing to convince regular users of the need to switch to a better choice,” Ramaswamy and Raghunathan continued.

Building the search engine was actually the easy part

I’ve talked with Neeva’s co-founders several times over the last couple of years, and their list of grievances here is long and well-founded. They’ve had to contend with the billion-dollar deals Google signs to make itself the default search engine on devices everywhere; the huge “are you sure you want to change?” popups that show up whenever you try to set a new default browser or search engine; the difficulty of finding those settings in the first place; the mess that is the Chrome Web Store; on and on and on. Anyone trying to build a new search engine is fighting a massively uphill battle.

Neeva was also a paid product, as the company tried to prove a business model for search other than ads and surveillance. “Contrary to popular belief,” the co-founders wrote in the blog post, “convincing users to pay for a better experience was actually a less difficult problem compared to getting them to try a new search engine in the first place.” Combine that with a tough economy, and Neeva simply couldn’t see a business path forward.

The timing here is really interesting. Neeva is shutting down at what might be the best moment in two decades for upstart search engines. Users are increasingly fed up with the ad load and subpar results they get from Google, and AI chatbots like Bing and ChatGPT have upended everyone’s idea about how to interact with the internet. Neeva bet on this, too, developing a large language model-based system called Neeva AI that is in many ways more useful than what you’ll get from Bing or Bard. But that wasn’t enough either.

The race to take down Google is still very much on, of course: Bing continues to push hard to gain market share, and Brave recently touted that it now runs completely on its own search stack. Companies like you.com and DuckDuckGo are also trying to re-think the way search works, and using AI to do so. But so far, it looks like Google’s only real competitor is, well, Google.

Neeva’s search engine will shut down on June 2. Going forward, Neeva will be “shifting to a new area of focus,” which seems likely to be LLM-based and related to the Snowflake acquisition. The company will be refunding users for the unused portion of their Neeva subscriptions, and deleting all user data. “We are truly grateful to our community,” the co-founders wrote, “and we are truly sorry that we aren’t able to continue to provide the search engine that you want and deserve.”
