conversation_input.content:
General Discussion
During communication, speakers produce visual cues signaling their confidence level in the content of their speech, which can reflect their word retrieval (Goodwin and Goodwin, 1986; Rimé and Schiaratura, 1991; Krauss et al., 1996) and/or their (un)conscious desire to communicate their mental state to others (Goodwin and Goodwin, 1986; Visser et al., 2014). However, it is unknown if observers use the visual cues from these cognitive and social processes when perceiving a speaker's confidence level. There is a lack of research investigating whether there is a difference between the types of visual cues speakers produce because of their transient confidence level and the types of visual cues observers use to assess this mental state. This study tested this issue in relation to a speaker's confidence for general knowledge facts by observers indicating the visual cues they used after evaluating a speaker's confidence level.


Effect of Situational Factors on Visual Cue Production and Evaluation
Compared to previous studies that report the occurrence of visual cues in relation to a speaker's confidence level, our results shed light on the frequency of these visual cues that speakers produce, and consequently their effect on observers' confidence evaluations. Overall, we found that speakers do not often produce changes in eye gaze, facial expressions and postural shifts, but when salient changes in these cues are produced, they can impact observers' evaluations. We postulate that one reason for this low frequency production of visual cues is due to the stakes level of social evaluation created by our experiment. A situation involving high-stakes social evaluation occurs when an individual (or group) has significant power to impact another's future (Gifford et al., 1985; Cuddy et al., 2012) such as in a job interview. Here, a speaker's speech content and their confidence level in this content, through vocal and visual cues, can greatly impact the outcome of their social interaction. In contrast, a situation of low-stakes social evaluation does not pose a risk to a speaker's social status. For example, a speaker may mundanely report inaccurate information due to inaccurately recalling (highly or less accessible) information and they will not face major social consequences for this (Depaulo et al., 1996; Gozna et al., 2001; Azizli et al., 2016). Our trivia question task may have simulated a situation of low-stakes social evaluation, in that if speakers answered a question incorrectly it did not have negative social consequences for them or their interaction with the examiner. The speakers did not know the examiner, the accuracy of their responses was not important for their social status, pausing due to word retrieval difficulties could occur because there was low social demand to respond quickly, and the questions were not used to elicit an emotional state in the speakers. This low-stakes context may explain why the speakers did not often produce postural shifts or happy, amused or embarrassed facial expressions based on their confidence level, as these cues are more often associated with situations involving social judgments and affect (Costa et al., 2001; Coleman and Wu, 2006; Hareli and Parkinson, 2008). Alternatively, the low frequency of embarrassed or amused facial expressions may have been related to the few instances where speakers answered questions about well-known general knowledge incorrectly (Table 1). Future research may explore the effect of shared knowledge that is known by the audience/observer on the visual cues that speakers produce and the visual cues that observers subsequently attend to. For example, if an observer knows the information that a speaker is trying to recall, or a speaker has difficulty recalling information that is well-known knowledge to an observer or audience; how do these situations affect a speaker's perceived confidence and the cues that observers attend to. This question may be addressed by examining the interaction between a speaker's visual and vocal cues on their perceived confidence.


This low-stakes context may also explain the small difference in speakers' perceived confidence ratings for high vs. low confidence. Since speakers were in a situation of low social stress, the quantity and types of visual cues they produced to indicate high vs. low confidence in their speech content, may have been less differentiated to observers. Future research may explore how the level of social evaluation in a given context can impact speaker's memory retrieval and visual cues as well as observers' evaluations. Nonetheless, we do not know if observers detected that speakers produced speech in a low-stakes context, and if detecting this context may have affected the types of visual cues used in their social evaluations.


Research on a speaker's transient confidence level based on their speech content has largely tested speakers' level of certainty for general knowledge facts (Smith and Clark, 1993; Brennan and Williams, 1995; Swerts and Krahmer, 2005). More research is needed to understand the impact of speakers' transient confidence level for other information, such as their opinions. This is particularly relevant when speakers are trying to persuade an audience of their stance, as the speech content may also elicit a greater emotional valence compared to responding to general knowledge questions. Here, speakers' responses, including their visual cues, are more likely to be socially evaluated by others such as an employer conducting a job interview (DeGroot and Motowidlo, 1999), a person on a date (Muehlenhard et al., 1986; Fichten et al., 1992; Ambady and Skowronski, 2008), a judge in court (Cramer et al., 2009), a customer interacting with a salesperson (Leigh and Summers, 2002), or a border security officer. Future research should explore this branch of a speaker's confidence in their speech content with greater consideration for situational factors. In these contexts, speakers may (un)consciously produce visual cues to save face (Goffman, 1967, 1971; Visser et al., 2014) or reinforce their level of certainty (Moons et al., 2013), and observers' evaluations of a speaker's confidence level via their non-verbal cues can have real social implications.


Limitations and Conclusions
One limitation of our study was our inter-rater reliability for the subcategories of visual cues speakers produced. Though the inter-rater agreement between the coders was significantly greater than chance, the coefficients did not indicate strong agreement. Thus, the detection of a speaker's visual cues may require more training as individuals can vary in their conceptualization of and identification for visual cues. Also, a speaker's production of eye movements to signal their confidence level may be influenced by their cultural background, in accordance with cultural display rules in the eyes and facial expressions (McCarthy et al., 2006, 2008). Our results were based on native speakers of Canadian English with various cultural backgrounds; controlling for this factor could help explain some of the variability between the speakers in the quantity and types of visual cues produced. Moreover, examining the effect of observers' cultural attitudes based on a speaker's physical appearance would also allow us to examine other types of social factors that may have influenced observers' confidence evaluations of speakers and whether the types of visual cues that observers used in their evaluations differed based on a speaker's physical appearance. Also, having a larger sample of speakers would allow us to increase the generalizability of our findings. Lastly, our study operated under the assumption that when observers only have access to the visual communication channel, they can accurately recall what visual cues they used in their evaluation of a speaker's confidence. It may be argued that this manipulation created an unnatural context to evaluate a speaker's confidence level, since in everyday communication observers have access to many communication channels and can assess a speaker's mental state in real time. On the other hand, there are also real-life contexts where observers have heightened attention for/use of the visual communication channel, such as interacting with speakers of a foreign or second language (Sueyoshi and Hardison, 2005) or listening to speech in a noisy environment (Neely, 1956). Use of an eye-tracking paradigm could provide an objective, real-time measure of the visual cues that observers used in their confidence evaluations. Nonetheless, observers rarely reported they did not know which visual cues they used in their evaluations. This result may indicate that when observers only have access to the visual communication channel, they are to some extent, aware of the visual cues they perceive.


In conclusion, this study showed that observers can accurately perceive a speaker's confidence level in the content of their speech in a low-stakes context based on their visual cues, by primarily using the speaker's facial expressions and eye movements. Observers may be socially attuned to salient, yet infrequent cues in the facial regions so they can efficiently infer a speaker's confidence level in the speech content. This social attention may be important as the stakes of the situation increase for speakers. Future research should explore using more video recordings of speakers' spontaneous speech and examining variability across speakers, to improve descriptions of the visual cues that speakers produce signaling their confidence level in the speech content. These methodological changes will better reflect the cues that aid in observers' assessments of a speaker's confidence level and their communicative interactions with others.

## Conclusions:

This study demonstrates that observers can accurately gauge a speaker's confidence level based solely on visual cues, primarily facial expressions and eye movements, even in low-stakes situations. This suggests a social attunement to subtle yet significant visual cues, particularly in the facial region, allowing for efficient inference of a speaker's confidence.  However, the study also highlights the infrequency of these visual cues in low-stakes scenarios, possibly due to the lack of social pressure. Future research should focus on analyzing spontaneous speech and individual speaker variations to better understand the nuances of these visual cues and their impact on social interactions, particularly in higher-stakes environments.

## Key Subjects and Explanations:

* **Visual Cues and Confidence:** The study investigated the relationship between visual cues produced by a speaker and an observer's perception of their confidence level. It found that despite the infrequency of these cues in low-stakes settings, observers could still accurately perceive confidence levels, primarily relying on facial expressions and eye movements.
* **Low-Stakes Context and Cue Production:** The study suggests that the low-stakes nature of the trivia task likely contributed to the infrequent production of visual cues related to confidence. This is attributed to the lack of social pressure and potential consequences for incorrect answers.
* **Impact of Social Evaluation:** The study proposes that higher-stakes situations, where social evaluation is more significant, might lead to more pronounced and frequent visual cues related to confidence. This highlights the potential influence of social context on both cue production and observer perception.
* **Limitations and Future Research:** The study acknowledges limitations such as inter-rater reliability for coding visual cues, cultural influences on cue production and perception, and the artificiality of restricting observers to only visual information.  Future research should address these limitations by examining spontaneous speech, individual speaker variations, and the impact of cultural factors.
* **Real-World Applications:**  The findings have implications for understanding communication in various real-world scenarios, including job interviews, legal proceedings, and sales interactions, where perceiving a speaker's confidence can be crucial for social judgment and decision-making.
* **Methodological Considerations:** The study highlights the need for more refined methodologies, such as eye-tracking, to objectively measure observer attention to visual cues and provide a more comprehensive understanding of the dynamics between visual cues, confidence perception, and social interaction.

This summary provides a concise overview of the study's key findings and implications, emphasizing the complex interplay between visual cues, confidence perception, and social context. It also highlights the need for continued research to further explore this fascinating area of human communication.

For example, if an observer knows the information that a speaker is trying to recall, or a speaker has difficulty recalling information that is well-known knowledge to an observer or audience; how do these situations affect a speaker's perceived confidence and the cues that observers attend to. This question may be addressed by examining the interaction between a speaker's visual and vocal cues on their perceived confidence.


This low-stakes context may also explain the small difference in speakers' perceived confidence ratings for high vs. low confidence. Since speakers were in a situation of low social stress, the quantity and types of visual cues they produced to indicate high vs. low confidence in their speech content, may have been less differentiated to observers. Future research may explore how the level of social evaluation in a given context can impact speaker's memory retrieval and visual cues as well as observers' evaluations. Nonetheless, we do not know if observers detected that speakers produced speech in a low-stakes context, and if detecting this context may have affected the types of visual cues used in their social evaluations.


Research on a speaker's transient confidence level based on their speech content has largely tested speakers' level of certainty for general knowledge facts (Smith and Clark, 1993; Brennan and Williams, 1995; Swerts and Krahmer, 2005). More research is needed to understand the impact of speakers' transient confidence level for other information, such as their opinions. This is particularly relevant when speakers are trying to persuade an audience of their stance, as the speech content may also elicit a greater emotional valence compared to responding to general knowledge questions. Here, speakers' responses, including their visual cues, are more likely to be socially evaluated by others such as an employer conducting a job interview (DeGroot and Motowidlo, 1999), a person on a date (Muehlenhard et al., 1986; Fichten et al., 1992; Ambady and Skowronski, 2008), a judge in court (Cramer et al., 2009), a customer interacting with a salesperson (Leigh and Summers, 2002), or a border security officer. Future research should explore this branch of a speaker's confidence in their speech content with greater consideration for situational factors. In these contexts, speakers may (un)consciously produce visual cues to save face (Goffman, 1967, 1971; Visser et al., 2014) or reinforce their level of certainty (Moons et al., 2013), and observers' evaluations of a speaker's confidence level via their non-verbal cues can have real social implications.


Limitations and Conclusions
One limitation of our study was our inter-rater reliability for the subcategories of visual cues speakers produced. Though the inter-rater agreement between the coders was significantly greater than chance, the coefficients did not indicate strong agreement. Thus, the detection of a speaker's visual cues may require more training as individuals can vary in their conceptualization of and identification for visual cues. Also, a speaker's production of eye movements to signal their confidence level may be influenced by their cultural background, in accordance with cultural display rules in the eyes and facial expressions (McCarthy et al., 2006, 2008). Our results were based on native speakers of Canadian English with various cultural backgrounds; controlling for this factor could help explain some of the variability between the speakers in the quantity and types of visual cues produced. Moreover, examining the effect of observers' cultural attitudes based on a speaker's physical appearance would also allow us to examine other types of social factors that may have influenced observers' confidence evaluations of speakers and whether the types of visual cues that observers used in their evaluations differed based on a speaker's physical appearance. Also, having a larger sample of speakers would allow us to increase the generalizability of our findings. Lastly, our study operated under the assumption that when observers only have access to the visual communication channel, they can accurately recall what visual cues they used in their evaluation of a speaker's confidence. It may be argued that this manipulation created an unnatural context to evaluate a speaker's confidence level, since in everyday communication observers have access to many communication channels and can assess a speaker's mental state in real time. On the other hand, there are also real-life contexts where observers have heightened attention for/use of the visual communication channel, such as interacting with speakers of a foreign or second language (Sueyoshi and Hardison, 2005) or listening to speech in a noisy environment (Neely, 1956). Use of an eye-tracking paradigm could provide an objective, real-time measure of the visual cues that observers used in their confidence evaluations. Nonetheless, observers rarely reported they did not know which visual cues they used in their evaluations. This result may indicate that when observers only have access to the visual communication channel, they are to some extent, aware of the visual cues they perceive.


In conclusion, this study showed that observers can accurately perceive a speaker's confidence level in the content of their speech in a low-stakes context based on their visual cues, by primarily using the speaker's facial expressions and eye movements. Observers may be socially attuned to salient, yet infrequent cues in the facial regions so they can efficiently infer a speaker's confidence level in the speech content. This social attention may be important as the stakes of the situation increase for speakers. Future research should explore using more video recordings of speakers' spontaneous speech and examining variability across speakers, to improve descriptions of the visual cues that speakers produce signaling their confidence level in the speech content. These methodological changes will better reflect the cues that aid in observers' assessments of a speaker's confidence level and their communicative interactions with others.

chosen.answer:
Here is a summary of the key points in conclusions and points of discussion:

Conclusions:
- Observers can accurately perceive a speaker's confidence level in the content of their speech based on visual cues like facial expressions and eye movements, even in a low-stakes context.  
- Observers may be socially attuned to detecting salient but infrequent visual cues in the facial region to efficiently infer a speaker's confidence level.

Points of discussion:

1. Effect of situational factors on cue production and evaluation
   - Speakers produced few visual cues like postural shifts or facial expressions due to the low-stakes nature of the task. Higher stakes may elicit more differentiated cues.
   - Observers' evaluations may be less differentiated for high vs low confidence due to low stakes context.

2. Impact of speech content 
   - More research is needed on confidence for opinions vs facts, and how content elicits emotion.
   - Cues may differ more for persuading audiences vs general knowledge.  

3. Cultural factors
   - Cue production and perception may vary by cultural display rules and attitudes.
   - Controlling for culture could help explain variability in cues.

4. Methodological limitations  
   - Inter-rater reliability on cues could be improved with more training.
   - Using video recordings and eye tracking would provide a more natural and objective assessment.
   - A larger sample would increase generalizability.

In summary, this research provided insights into how visual cues communicate confidence levels in speech and the role of situational factors, while calling for more exploration of cultural, content-related and methodological aspects.

During communication, speakers produce visual cues signaling their confidence level in the content of their speech, which can reflect their word retrieval (Goodwin and Goodwin, 1986; Rimé and Schiaratura, 1991; Krauss et al., 1996) and/or their (un)conscious desire to communicate their mental state to others (Goodwin and Goodwin, 1986; Visser et al., 2014). However, it is unknown if observers use the visual cues from these cognitive and social processes when perceiving a speaker's confidence level. There is a lack of research investigating whether there is a difference between the types of visual cues speakers produce because of their transient confidence level and the types of visual cues observers use to assess this mental state. This study tested this issue in relation to a speaker's confidence for general knowledge facts by observers indicating the visual cues they used after evaluating a speaker's confidence level.


Effect of Situational Factors on Visual Cue Production and Evaluation
Compared to previous studies that report the occurrence of visual cues in relation to a speaker's confidence level, our results shed light on the frequency of these visual cues that speakers produce, and consequently their effect on observers' confidence evaluations. Overall, we found that speakers do not often produce changes in eye gaze, facial expressions and postural shifts, but when salient changes in these cues are produced, they can impact observers' evaluations. We postulate that one reason for this low frequency production of visual cues is due to the stakes level of social evaluation created by our experiment. A situation involving high-stakes social evaluation occurs when an individual (or group) has significant power to impact another's future (Gifford et al., 1985; Cuddy et al., 2012) such as in a job interview. Here, a speaker's speech content and their confidence level in this content, through vocal and visual cues, can greatly impact the outcome of their social interaction. In contrast, a situation of low-stakes social evaluation does not pose a risk to a speaker's social status. For example, a speaker may mundanely report inaccurate information due to inaccurately recalling (highly or less accessible) information and they will not face major social consequences for this (Depaulo et al., 1996; Gozna et al., 2001; Azizli et al., 2016). Our trivia question task may have simulated a situation of low-stakes social evaluation, in that if speakers answered a question incorrectly it did not have negative social consequences for them or their interaction with the examiner. The speakers did not know the examiner, the accuracy of their responses was not important for their social status, pausing due to word retrieval difficulties could occur because there was low social demand to respond quickly, and the questions were not used to elicit an emotional state in the speakers. chosen.answer:
## Conclusions:

This study demonstrates that observers can accurately gauge a speaker's confidence level based solely on visual cues, primarily facial expressions and eye movements, even in low-stakes situations. This suggests a social attunement to subtle yet significant visual cues, particularly in the facial region, allowing for efficient inference of a speaker's confidence.  However, the study also highlights the infrequency of these visual cues in low-stakes scenarios, possibly due to the lack of social pressure. Future research should focus on analyzing spontaneous speech and individual speaker variations to better understand the nuances of these visual cues and their impact on social interactions, particularly in higher-stakes environments.

## Key Subjects and Explanations:

* **Visual Cues and Confidence:** The study investigated the relationship between visual cues produced by a speaker and an observer's perception of their confidence level. It found that despite the infrequency of these cues in low-stakes settings, observers could still accurately perceive confidence levels, primarily relying on facial expressions and eye movements.
* **Low-Stakes Context and Cue Production:** The study suggests that the low-stakes nature of the trivia task likely contributed to the infrequent production of visual cues related to confidence. This is attributed to the lack of social pressure and potential consequences for incorrect answers.
* **Impact of Social Evaluation:** The study proposes that higher-stakes situations, where social evaluation is more significant, might lead to more pronounced and frequent visual cues related to confidence. This highlights the potential influence of social context on both cue production and observer perception.
* **Limitations and Future Research:** The study acknowledges limitations such as inter-rater reliability for coding visual cues, cultural influences on cue production and perception, and the artificiality of restricting observers to only visual information.  Future research should address these limitations by examining spontaneous speech, individual speaker variations, and the impact of cultural factors.
* **Real-World Applications:**  The findings have implications for understanding communication in various real-world scenarios, including job interviews, legal proceedings, and sales interactions, where perceiving a speaker's confidence can be crucial for social judgment and decision-making.
* **Methodological Considerations:** The study highlights the need for more refined methodologies, such as eye-tracking, to objectively measure observer attention to visual cues and provide a more comprehensive understanding of the dynamics between visual cues, confidence perception, and social interaction.

This summary provides a concise overview of the study's key findings and implications, emphasizing the complex interplay between visual cues, confidence perception, and social context. It also highlights the need for continued research to further explore this fascinating area of human communication.

conversation_input.content:
Generate an executive summary for the brochure below

1.0	Introduction
The introduction of the Cola Juicy sub-brand by Coca-Cola is based on the parent brand's position and emerging trends in the children's beverage market. The rationale behind its introduction lies in the growing demand for healthier beverage options for kids, driven by concerns about childhood obesity and the impact of sugary drinks on children's health.
By launching Cola Juicy, Coca-Cola aims to fill the gap in the market for parents seeking healthier options for their children. This strategy allows the company to expand its product line and cater to a specific market segment, namely children. By targeting this demographic, Coca-Cola can establish a loyal customer base that will potentially continue to purchase Coca-Cola products as they grow older.
2.0	Brand Identity of the new sub-brand
The brand identity of Coca-Cola’s juicy sub-brand is focused on establishing its dominance in the emerging market of children’s beverages. The brand identity encompasses both external and internal aspects.
2.1	External Brand Identity: This entails how the physical outlook, features and characteristics of Coca-Cola Juicy establish its brand positioning in the market. This includes;
Logo: The sub-brand logo features a playful and vibrant design, incorporating elements that resonate with children, such as fruit illustrations or cartoon characters. The logo will be visually appealing and easily recognizable. See apendix
Tagline: A catchy and memorable tagline that can convey the essence of the sub-brand (Kapferer, 2016). It is tagged “The taste you can trust”. See apendix
Typeface: The choice of typeface should align with the target audience and evoke a sense of fun and energy (Kapferer, 2016). A friendly and legible typeface, with rounded edges and vibrant colours, could be suitable for the sub-brand messaging.
Brand Colors: The colour palette for Cola Juicy will be bright and vibrant, capturing the attention of children (Keller & Lehmann, 2003). Colours like orange, green, red, and yellow will be used to convey energy, freshness, and fun.
2.2	Internal Brand Identity: This entails the identity of Coca-cola Juicy within the company. This includes;
Brand Culture: The sub-brand will foster a culture that promotes health, well-being, and enjoyment for children. The internal brand culture could focus on creating a positive and inclusive environment, where teamwork, creativity, and innovation are encouraged (Interbrand, 2020).
Brand Ethos: The ethos of Cola Juicy will revolve around providing children with delicious and refreshing beverage options that prioritize their health and wellness. It should emphasize the use of natural ingredients, sustainability, and transparency in sourcing and production processes (Aaker, 2012).
Brand Purpose: The purpose of Cola Juicy is to revolutionize the children's beverage market by offering healthier alternatives that are both enjoyable and beneficial for kids. The sub-brand purpose is to address the concerns of parents about sugary drinks and provide them with a trusted and appealing option for their children (Olins, 2008).
2.3	Positioning in the Market: Cola Juicy can position itself as a leader in the market for healthier children's beverages. It can differentiate itself by emphasizing its low-sugar content, natural ingredients, and wide range of appealing flavours. The sub-brands positioning should focus on meeting the needs and desires of both children and parents. It should communicate the fun and flavorful experience that Cola Juicy offers while assuring parents of its nutritional benefits. 

3.0	The Value Proposition 
The value proposition of the Cola Juicy sub-brand lies in its ability to attract consumers from both functional and emotional perspectives, offering a unique and enjoyable experience throughout the customer journey. From a functional perspective, Cola Juicy's low-sugar content and use of natural ingredients make it an attractive choice for health-conscious parents. It addresses their concerns about their children's sugar intake while providing a flavorful alternative to traditional sugary beverages. The sub-brand wide range of appealing flavours, such as strawberry, orange, apple, and vanilla, caters to children's taste preferences, enhancing its functional appeal (Davis, 2017).
From an emotional perspective, Cola Juicy aims to create a positive and engaging brand experience for children. The playful branding, vibrant packaging, and cartoon-like imagery contribute to the sub-brand appeal, capturing children's attention and fostering a sense of fun and excitement. The sub-brand emphasis on health and well-being aligns with parents' emotional desires to provide their children with nutritious options (Davis, 2017). 
The consumer experience of the Cola Juicy sub-brand is designed to be enjoyable and memorable. Starting with the initial discovery and interaction with the playful packaging and vibrant branding, consumers, especially children, are drawn to the sub-brands appealing visual elements. The availability of a variety of flavours adds to the excitement, allowing children to choose their preferred option (Kapferer, 2012).
In terms of subsequent interactions, Cola Juicy can engage with consumers through various channels, such as social media, where they can share their experiences, participate in contests, and provide feedback. By actively involving consumers in these interactions, the sub-brand strengthens its relationship with its target audience, fostering loyalty and advocacy.

4.0	The Launch Tactics of the New Sub-Brand
The launch of the Cola Juicy sub-brand will employ various tactics to create awareness, generate interest, and establish a strong market presence. These include;
Behavioural Marketing: Targeted online advertisements and social media promotions can also be used to reach parents and children who have shown interest in healthier beverage options.
Content Marketing: This can include blog posts, videos, and social media content that focus on topics such as healthy hydration for kids, the importance of natural ingredients, and fun recipe ideas using Cola Juicy as an ingredient. The content should be shareable, valuable, and aligned with the sub-brands messaging.
Influencer Partnerships: Collaborating with relevant influencers can help reach a wider audience and build credibility. Identifying influencers who specialize in parenting, health, or nutrition-related content can allow Cola Juicy to tap into their established communities. 
Public Relations: Leveraging public relations strategies can generate media coverage and buzz around the sub-brand (de Chernatony & McDonald, 2003). Press releases can be distributed to relevant media outlets, highlighting the sub-brand launch, mission, and unique selling points. 
Going forward, the management of the Cola Juicy sub-brand will focus on several key aspects:
Product Quality and Innovation: Continuous attention to product quality, taste, and nutritional value is essential to maintain customer satisfaction and meet evolving consumer expectations (Keller, 2013). 
Customer Feedback and Engagement: Regularly interacting with customers through social media, surveys, and events can foster loyalty and improve brand perception.
Marketing and Communication: A consistent marketing and communication strategy is crucial for ongoing brand management (Keller, 2008). This includes maintaining an active online presence, leveraging social media platforms, and regularly updating the sub-brand website with engaging and informative content

chosen.answer: Coca-Cola is launching a new sub-brand, Cola Juicy, targeted at the growing market for healthier children's beverages. This initiative addresses parental concerns about sugary drinks and childhood obesity by offering a low-sugar, naturally flavored alternative. Cola Juicy will leverage a playful brand identity with vibrant colors and engaging imagery to appeal to children, while simultaneously highlighting its health benefits to resonate with parents. The launch will be supported by a comprehensive marketing strategy encompassing behavioral and content marketing, influencer partnerships, and public relations efforts. Long-term success will rely on maintaining product quality, actively engaging with customers, and implementing a consistent marketing and communication strategy. Cola Juicy aims to establish itself as a leader in the healthy children's beverage market, fostering brand loyalty from a young age and potentially securing future Coca-Cola consumers.

The sub-brand's brand identity is designed to appeal to children and parents, with a playful and vibrant logo, tagline, typeface, and color palette. Cola Juicy's internal brand identity focuses on promoting health, well-being, and enjoyment for children, with a culture of teamwork, creativity, and innovation.

The sub-brand's value proposition lies in its ability to offer a unique and enjoyable experience for both children and parents, with a wide range of appealing flavors, low-sugar content, and natural ingredients. The consumer experience is designed to be engaging, with playful packaging, vibrant branding, and interactive social media campaigns.

The launch tactics for Cola Juicy include targeted online advertisements, social media promotions, content marketing, influencer partnerships, and public relations strategies. Ongoing brand management will focus on product quality and innovation, customer feedback and engagement, and consistent marketing and communication strategies.

With its unique brand identity, value proposition, and launch tactics, Cola Juicy is poised to establish itself as a leader in the market for healthier children's beverages, while expanding Coca-Cola's product line and catering to a specific market segment. By leveraging the power of a strong brand, Cola Juicy can create a loyal customer base and contribute to the parent brand's continued growth and success.

Product Quality and Innovation: Continuous attention to product quality, taste, and nutritional value is essential to maintain customer satisfaction and meet evolving consumer expectations (Keller, 2013).

3.0	The Value Proposition 
The value proposition of the Cola Juicy sub-brand lies in its ability to attract consumers from both functional and emotional perspectives, offering a unique and enjoyable experience throughout the customer journey. From a functional perspective, Cola Juicy's low-sugar content and use of natural ingredients make it an attractive choice for health-conscious parents. It addresses their concerns about their children's sugar intake while providing a flavorful alternative to traditional sugary beverages. The sub-brand wide range of appealing flavours, such as strawberry, orange, apple, and vanilla, caters to children's taste preferences, enhancing its functional appeal (Davis, 2017).
From an emotional perspective, Cola Juicy aims to create a positive and engaging brand experience for children. The playful branding, vibrant packaging, and cartoon-like imagery contribute to the sub-brand appeal, capturing children's attention and fostering a sense of fun and excitement. The sub-brand emphasis on health and well-being aligns with parents' emotional desires to provide their children with nutritious options (Davis, 2017). 
The consumer experience of the Cola Juicy sub-brand is designed to be enjoyable and memorable. Starting with the initial discovery and interaction with the playful packaging and vibrant branding, consumers, especially children, are drawn to the sub-brands appealing visual elements. The availability of a variety of flavours adds to the excitement, allowing children to choose their preferred option (Kapferer, 2012).
In terms of subsequent interactions, Cola Juicy can engage with consumers through various channels, such as social media, where they can share their experiences, participate in contests, and provide feedback. By actively involving consumers in these interactions, the sub-brand strengthens its relationship with its target audience, fostering loyalty and advocacy.

4.0	The Launch Tactics of the New Sub-Brand
The launch of the Cola Juicy sub-brand will employ various tactics to create awareness, generate interest, and establish a strong market presence. These include;
Behavioural Marketing: Targeted online advertisements and social media promotions can also be used to reach parents and children who have shown interest in healthier beverage options.
Content Marketing: This can include blog posts, videos, and social media content that focus on topics such as healthy hydration for kids, the importance of natural ingredients, and fun recipe ideas using Cola Juicy as an ingredient. The content should be shareable, valuable, and aligned with the sub-brands messaging.
Influencer Partnerships: Collaborating with relevant influencers can help reach a wider audience and build credibility. Identifying influencers who specialize in parenting, health, or nutrition-related content can allow Cola Juicy to tap into their established communities. 
Public Relations: Leveraging public relations strategies can generate media coverage and buzz around the sub-brand (de Chernatony & McDonald, 2003). Press releases can be distributed to relevant media outlets, highlighting the sub-brand launch, mission, and unique selling points. 
Going forward, the management of the Cola Juicy sub-brand will focus on several key aspects:
Product Quality and Innovation: Continuous attention to product quality, taste, and nutritional value is essential to maintain customer satisfaction and meet evolving consumer expectations (Keller, 2013). 
Customer Feedback and Engagement: Regularly interacting with customers through social media, surveys, and events can foster loyalty and improve brand perception.
Marketing and Communication: A consistent marketing and communication strategy is crucial for ongoing brand management (Keller, 2008). This includes maintaining an active online presence, leveraging social media platforms, and regularly updating the sub-brand website with engaging and informative content

**Executive Summary**

The Cola Juicy sub-brand is a strategic initiative by Coca-Cola to capture the growing market demand for healthier children's beverages. Leveraging the parent brand's position, Cola Juicy targets health-conscious parents seeking alternative options with low sugar content and natural ingredients.

Its brand identity emphasizes a playful and vibrant aesthetic, with a tagline and logo tailored to children. Internally, the sub-brand fosters a culture of health and well-being, driven by a purpose to provide nutritious and enjoyable beverages.

Cola Juicy's value proposition combines functional benefits, such as low sugar and natural ingredients, with an emotional appeal that resonates with children. It offers a wide range of flavors to cater to taste preferences and creates a memorable and engaging consumer experience through playful branding and interactive marketing campaigns.

Launch tactics include behavioral marketing, content marketing, influencer partnerships, and public relations to raise awareness and generate interest. Future management focuses on product quality, customer feedback, and ongoing marketing and communication to maintain brand loyalty and perception. By addressing the concerns of parents and engaging with children, Cola Juicy aims to establish a dominant position in the healthier children's beverage market.

conversation_input.content:
Please create a synopsis of the following text with insights on the themes and morals contained. The Text: L is for limits I'm still searching for mine
there might still be a white knight somewhere deep in my mind
this one is a classic a fairy tale with a twist
 some misaligned motives and an end that just fits
not Cinderella, Rapunzel or Little Red riding hood
there's no 3 little pigs in a house made of wood

Just a musical man in a foreign land 
who when he needs money offers a hand
vanquishing the vermin and getting rid of rats 
and with them the chance of a black plague attack

The town was infested, a scene in the streets 
black mats of foul fur churned greasy in heaps
dark eyes on the rooftops, whiskers under doors 
transgressed between holes as they scurried across floors

From outside the gate and over the hill came the clicks of expensive leather boots
a whistle on the wind, lonely and slow, the subtle swishing of a crushed velvet suit
he had a wide brimmed hat, a guitar on his back and a leather strap matching his kicks
"I know who ye are" as he steps toward the bar, "and You clearly have a problem that I can fix"

He motioned to the whistle hung by chain on his chest, a shiny silver symbol that tended to impress
who hadn't heard the rumors about the rat mans skill, a solitary mercenary using tunes to kill 
just then a fat rat ran across his right boot, His left pinned the tail and he gave a short toot
as the silver pipe barked the rodent collapsed, his eyes glazed over and he rolled on his back

That's my stock in trade - I deal with mice, 
or rats and possums, roaming rodents and the like
if you want your town back I'll need a shovel and a check 
payable on completion and some professional respect

The document was drafted and the details defined, 
he left for the outskirts once the contract was signed
near the steep cliff overlooking the fjord, 
he dug a deep pit that he covered with a board

He he wiped sweat from his brow and trudged toward town 
he was happy for work but didn't like getting screwed around
some towns were notorious for dishonored deals
this was not his first concert but things still might get real

He cracked his knuckles and whet his lips 
his whistle at the ready, he inhaled and let rip
a long string of notes in slow steady waves 
a call to the rodents entrancing the slaves

In the streets rank and file from the smallest of mice 
to the fat cat sized rats that make women run for their lives
he beat a steady drum with the heals of his boots 
walking toward the cliff and the pit he'd  dug to use

When he reached the excavation and he pulled aside the board
at the steep sided pit in the field by the fjord
he circled round and played the few last bars of siren song
wave after wave fell into the cave as more marched helplessly along

A half hour later he was standing at the bank
his check in hand as planned, but no surprise, no thanks
the teller acted agitated and said to sit and wait
there had been some dispute o'er the signature and date

This will take seven or eight days to clear
the mayor's gone on business you're gonna have to hang round here 
until he gets back and endorses your pay
you can rent a room at the saloon down-the-street and cross-the-way

He shook his head and set his jaw as he walked toward the door
the smirking sheriff snorted, his town had chosen war
as the townsfolk cleaned off rat piss and scrubbed the baseboards down
they were clearly complicit in the actions of the town

They laughed and leered while others jeered 
but not one single soul offered thanks
to them just a game, not an ounce of shame 
for his treatment by the cashier at the bank

He flashed back to his teacher at the music academy 
lecturing on theory and getting things right
his mind was decided this hamlet needed tragedy 
his finger traced the latches there'd be recompense tonight

As midnight approached he walked to the well 
and tuned the strings slowly as he sat upon the sill
for bigger game a bigger weapon as he strapped the six-string on, 
warming up and stretching well before unleashing sirens song

With the cascade of notes came a shuffle of soft steps
treading slowly entranced while the men in town slept
none of the women could resist the tunes allure
and the musicians intent to be done once and for sure

A choir in their bed cloths in the moonlight in the square
then marched toward the cliffs and the hell that waited there
at first he had the thought of escorting to the pit
the wife of the mayor and her two bratty kids

A sadistically simplistic way to render them as meat
the starving rats in the fresh dug pit could enjoy a midnight treat
At the very last minute just before they fell in
he altered the melody and they started to spin

As they rotated they disrobed dropping linens in a heap
waltzing naked in the wind while twirling in their sleep
the granny's less their panties and the aunts sans pants 
joined uncovered mothers, dozing daughters in the rat mans dance

This very famous waterfall they call the ladies leap
once had another name before the events of which I speak
they spun into the current tragic magic in their slumber
awakened by the water just before it took them under

With half of the populace washed clean of their sins
he turned back toward town and considered the men
it came all at once in it's poetic conclusion
a final solution of artistic retribution

Uncovering the pit, he dropped in the board
and up came an army in a starving rat horde
A flurry of notes and the rats stood transfixed
melodically commanded they swayed while whiskers twitched

At some deep level they understood he intended mocking
so rat infested bedclothes climbed above the rat filled stockings
the slippers writhed with mice and squeaked as rodent legs touched down
compelled by the musician as they could not resist the sound

While you wear this whistle they will obey your command
he remembered witching words from the far and foreign lands
but this was too much, he broke concentration
and choked on his spit as he laughed in frustration

As the feminine shapes fell in heaps at his feet
he thought of the men in the village fast asleep
a night eating and drinking free of the rats
boasts from the sheriff that there won't be a tax

Tomorrow the ratter will be escorted from town
told to be gone, he's not needed around
surely black magic and you best not return
the church will be informed, circle back and you'll burn

He would make them an example to always pay the bill
you don't leave an enemy an axe to grind or time to kill
snot nosed kids abruptly awoken cold and crying for their mama's
didn't have time to dwell on their dads, once confronted with rat filled pajamas

The alleys eerie and silent when the whistling finally stopped
just the distant click on cobbles and a swishing low and soft
windows stayed shuttered seven nights and seven days
no smoke from the chimneys, the mayor returns from time away

A week of fine feasting had made the rats round
and the extra excreta increased by the pound
the men reduced to meaty meals but where were the ladies?
their clothing located with the remains of their babies 

He found his door ajar ,as were all the doors he passed
as if they'd been propped open, an invitation to the rats
he slipped in the filth and tripped cross the threshold sprawling to the floor
in his private sanctum,now his dank destroyed den, he then found something more

The mortified mayor regarded the carnage 
He knew his mind was slipping but had kept it to himself 
the crumbling facade had clearly come to focus 
when he forgot to sign the check and had instead enjoyed his wealth

Above the cold hearth tacked to the mantle 
a hand written invoice, diagonally canceled
Services rendered. Unable to pay. 
Thanks for your business. Have a nice day.

chosen.answer:
The poem "L is for Limits" tells the story of a rat catcher who is hired by a town to deal with their rodent infestation problem. The rat catcher, who is also a musician, uses his musical skills to enthrall the rats and lead them to a cliff, where they fall into a pit and are killed. However, the townspeople do not pay the rat catcher as promised, and he seeks revenge by using his music to enthrall the town's women and lead them to their deaths in the same pit. The poem explores themes of betrayal, revenge, and the power of music to control and manipulate.

The rat catcher is portrayed as a mysterious and skilled figure, who is able to control the rats with his music and lead them to their deaths. He is also shown to be a vengeful character, who is willing to use his powers for personal gain and to punish those who have wronged him. The townspeople, on the other hand, are portrayed as dishonest and ungrateful, who do not appreciate the rat catcher's services and fail to pay him as promised.

The poem also touches on the theme of the abuse of power, as the rat catcher uses his musical abilities to control and manipulate others for his own gain. The poem suggests that those who have power over others must be careful not to abuse it, lest they face the consequences.

The tone of the poem is dark and macabre, with a touch of irony and humor. The use of rhyming and meter adds a musical quality to the poem, which enhances the theme of music as a powerful force. The imagery and language used are vivid and graphic, creating a vivid picture of the town's infestation problem and the rat catcher's gruesome solution.

Overall, "L is for Limits" is a thought-provoking and entertaining poem that explores the themes of power, revenge, and the consequences of dishonesty. The use of music as a tool for control and manipulation adds a unique twist to the story, making it a memorable and engaging read.

The poem explores the theme of limits and the consequences of greed, as well as the importance of ethical behavior and the consequences of unethical behavior. The protagonist eventually finds his services are needed elsewhere and departs, leaving the town to confront the damage caused by their greed and negligence.

chosen.answer:
**Synopsis**

A solitary musician, known as the "Rat Man," arrives in a town infested with rats. Despite his successful extermination, the townsfolk refuse to pay him, leading to a series of tragic events. The musician's revenge ultimately exposes the hypocrisy and corruption of the town.

**Themes and Morals**

**The Dangers of Greed and Betrayal:** The townsfolk's refusal to pay the musician for his services demonstrates their greed and lack of integrity. Their actions lead to their own demise, as the musician's revenge exposes their dark secrets.

**The Power of Music:** Music plays a central role throughout the story. The Rat Man's whistle commands the rodents, while his musical performance also captivates the women of the town. It highlights the transformative and seductive power of music.

**The Importance of Gratitude:** The town's ingratitude towards the musician sets the stage for their downfall. True gratitude is more than just a polite gesture; it is essential for maintaining societal harmony.

**The Nature of Justice:** The musician's actions are morally ambiguous. While he is justified in seeking retribution, his methods are extreme and ultimately harm innocent bystanders. The story raises questions about the nature of justice and the limits of revenge.

**The Consequences of Unbridled Power:** When the musician realizes the extent of his power over the rats, he becomes overwhelmed and unable to control them. This demonstrates the dangers of unchecked power and the importance of humility.

**Additional Insights**

* The story's fairy tale elements (e.g., the "white knight") subvert traditional tropes to create a darker and more complex narrative.
* The "ladies' leap" waterfall symbolizes the women's liberation from societal norms and their tragic fate.
* The Rat Man's transformation into a vengeful figure highlights the corrosive effects of betrayal and the potential for good to turn into evil.

Here is a synopsis of the text with analysis of its themes and morals:

This story tells of a traveling musician who uses his musical talents to rid a town of rats. However, when the town refuses to pay him as agreed, he takes revenge in a darkly poetic way. 

Key themes explored include keeping one's word/honoring agreements, the dangers of crossing or disrespecting someone with specialized skills, and the power of music/art. There are also themes of morality, justice, and the consequences of one's actions.

After successfully exterminating the rats, the musician is not paid as the contract stipulated. Seeing this as a betrayal, he decides to use his musical abilities for vengeance instead of help. He lures all the townswomen to their deaths by a cliff, then commands the starving rats to invade the town and homes. 

This shows the moral that one should not break agreements or take others for granted, as there may be unforeseen consequences. It also illustrates how specialized skills could potentially be misused if the skilled individual feels wronged. 

The gruesome yet artistic nature of the musician's revenge highlights how the creative arts have the power both to soothe and destroy. It leaves an unsettling message about respecting an artist's talents and integrity.

Overall, the dark tale serves as a cautionary fable about the importance of keeping one's word, honoring contracts, and not crossing those with unique abilities one has relied upon, lest the tables suddenly turn with tragic results. Music, meant to charm, is twisted to enact a grim form of poetic justice.

As the feminine shapes fell in heaps at his feet
he thought of the men in the village fast asleep
a night eating and drinking free of the rats
boasts from the sheriff that there won't be a tax

Tomorrow the ratter will be escorted from town
told to be gone, he's not needed around
surely black magic and you best not return
the church will be informed, circle back and you'll burn

He would make them an example to always pay the bill
you don't leave an enemy an axe to grind or time to kill
snot nosed kids abruptly awoken cold and crying for their mama's
didn't have time to dwell on their dads, once confronted with rat filled pajamas

The alleys eerie and silent when the whistling finally stopped
just the distant click on cobbles and a swishing low and soft
windows stayed shuttered seven nights and seven days
no smoke from the chimneys, the mayor returns from time away

A week of fine feasting had made the rats round
and the extra excreta increased by the pound
the men reduced to meaty meals but where were the ladies?
their clothing located with the remains of their babies 

He found his door ajar ,as were all the doors he passed
as if they'd been propped open, an invitation to the rats
he slipped in the filth and tripped cross the threshold sprawling to the floor
in his private sanctum,now his dank destroyed den, he then found something more

The mortified mayor regarded the carnage 
He knew his mind was slipping but had kept it to himself 
the crumbling facade had clearly come to focus 
when he forgot to sign the check and had instead enjoyed his wealth

Above the cold hearth tacked to the mantle 
a hand written invoice, diagonally canceled
Services rendered. Unable to pay. 
Thanks for your business. Have a nice day.

chosen.answer:
**Synopsis**

A solitary musician, known as the "Rat Man," arrives in a town infested with rats. Despite his successful extermination, the townsfolk refuse to pay him, leading to a series of tragic events. The musician's revenge ultimately exposes the hypocrisy and corruption of the town.

**Themes and Morals**

**The Dangers of Greed and Betrayal:** The townsfolk's refusal to pay the musician for his services demonstrates their greed and lack of integrity. Their actions lead to their own demise, as the musician's revenge exposes their dark secrets.

**The Power of Music:** Music plays a central role throughout the story. The Rat Man's whistle commands the rodents, while his musical performance also captivates the women of the town. It highlights the transformative and seductive power of music.

**The Importance of Gratitude:** The town's ingratitude towards the musician sets the stage for their downfall. True gratitude is more than just a polite gesture; it is essential for maintaining societal harmony.

**The Nature of Justice:** The musician's actions are morally ambiguous. While he is justified in seeking retribution, his methods are extreme and ultimately harm innocent bystanders. The story raises questions about the nature of justice and the limits of revenge.

**The Consequences of Unbridled Power:** When the musician realizes the extent of his power over the rats, he becomes overwhelmed and unable to control them. This demonstrates the dangers of unchecked power and the importance of humility.

**Additional Insights**

* The story's fairy tale elements (e.g., the "white knight") subvert traditional tropes to create a darker and more complex narrative.
* The "ladies' leap" waterfall symbolizes the women's liberation from societal norms and their tragic fate.
* The Rat Man's transformation into a vengeful figure highlights the corrosive effects of betrayal and the potential for good to turn into evil.

Synopsis and Themes:

The text is a creative reinterpretation of the classic fairy tale, with the musical rat-catcher as the protagonist. The story is set in a town infested with rats, and the rat-catcher is called upon to vanquish them. He uses his musical skills to lure the rats into a pit, and the town's people are relieved of their rat problem. However, when it comes time for him to be paid, the town's people break their promise to pay him for his services, leading to a series of events where the rat-catcher takes revenge on the town by using his music to control the rats, turning them against the people.

The themes present in the text include the consequences of broken promises, the corrupting influence of power, and the idea of just deserts. The rat-catcher is a victim of the town's people's dishonesty, and his revenge is a form of justice for the wrongs committed against him. The story also explores the idea of the corrupting influence of power, as the rat-catcher's ability to control the rats leads him to take increasingly drastic measures against the town's people.

The moral of the story is that broken promises and dishonesty have consequences, and that those who wield power must be careful not to let it corrupt them. The rat-catcher's revenge, while justified in some ways, ultimately leads to further chaos and destruction, highlighting the idea that two wrongs don't make a right. The story also highlights the importance of honesty and integrity, and the dangers of exploiting others for personal gain.

conversation_input.content:
Marketing Objective:
To have a significant SOV in Water Purifier Category whilst maintaining the CPO (Cost Per Order)
The objective was to increase E-Commerce sales while maintaining the campaign ROAS at adequate levels. As
Blue Star has been selling their WP only on market places & Amazon is the biggest volume contributor to
online channels. Hence, it became the first point of attack.
To achieve this aim, strategies were created to incorporate an integrated growth plan on the marketplaces &
other digital channels for Blue Star Water Purifiers. The business objectives were defined as follows –
1. Gain higher market share within the Water Purifier category for Blue Star
2. Building awareness for Water Purifier & building the sustainable sales funnel throughout the year
3. Increase SOV on marketplaces to build sturdy consideration funnel
Target Audience:
This was search campaign on Amazon & Flipkart, audience selected was prospects who have searched in the
past and are searching for keywords related to Water Purifiers. Eg. Brand, generic & Competition keywords
The Situation Analysis:
Blue Star is relatively a new entrant in the Water Purifier category with no TOMA/consideration on the product
line. It was challenging to convert consumers from their existing choice/brand recall for competitors like Kent
and Aqua Guard by Eureka Forbes to our product.
Being a new entrant they have less variety of products. The major challenge was that our hero product (Aristo)
(which had the best conversion rate) went off the shelf just a couple of weeks before the festival sale on
Marketplaces (Diwali Sale). Now, since our most reliable product was off the shelf we had a newly introduced
product in the market which was cost-wise a bit similar to the hero product. Challenge was to build the entire
ACT/performance funnel (Awareness, Consideration and Trial) around the new product within no time.Category Insights:
The category is heavily dominated by established players like Kent, HUL and Eureka Forbes (Aquaguard). In this
category user’s purchase cycle usually consists of 6-7years. India residential water purifier market was valued
at $ 391.4 million in 2019 and is projected to grow at a CAGR of 13.3% and reach $ 818 million by 2024.
Anticipated growth in the market can be attributed to growing concern towards water borne disease due to
water pollution, industrial development leading to water pollution and rising disposable income of Indians. The
product requires to have features basis the availability of water in that location eg. Hard water & soft water
which requires RO, UV(Ultraviolet), UF, activated carbon & alkaline.
Solution: Bottom to Mid Approach
Bottom Funnel (Identify the cash cow as in SKU)
1. New campaign structure implemented with all ad format (SP,SB,SBV & SD) and targeting 1 ASIN
(SKU) per campaign to identify best performing product and allocate budgets accordingly
2. Segmenting campaigns based on keyword theme - Brand, Generic and Competition
3. High Volume Generic keywords (identified from Amazon Pi) were targeted in separate campaigns
with higher bids against the suggested bids to deliver high impression share on top of the search
placement
4. Defence Strategy was implemented by targeting own Brand ASIN to protect them from
Competitors advertising on it
5. According to past learnings, competition ASIN & category targeting campaigns were running
parallel. Targeting individual ASINs can help improve attributed sales results, while Category
targeting can help improve the reach of the campaign. Separate campaigns for each Top
Competition Brand (for example Kent, Eureka Forbes, Pureit etc) were created to improve Sales
and acquire share from competition brands
6. Leveraged Sponsored display through retargeted mid funnel customers by Category, advertised
product & similar to advertised product view remarketing in for driving higher GVs.
7. Spends on Social Media campaigns were increased on weekends which further helped scale the
campaigns on Amazon as Conversion Rates were comparatively better on weekends vs the
weekdays (Landing page to be Amazon store)
8. With constant monitoring and optimization we made sure all campaigns have ample budgets to
run throughout the day
9. With internal tools (Amazon Pi, Power Bi & Helium10) and previous data bids optimized along
with dayparting to maximize the conversions during best performing hours
Tangible Outputs -
 Glance Views skyrocketed
 The brand searches saw a significant increase while the ads on Social Media were active
 It increased traffic relevance & time spent on product detailed pagesBusiness Results:
 The newly-introduced ASIN (Cresto) was ranking 1st in the Best Sellers on Amazon in the category
during Oct ART (Diwali Sale), and sealed the month with a growth of 413% in Orders compared to last
year Oct ART (Fig-1) (source: Amazon Ads Dashboard)
 September - October were the months when we had nearly 80% GVs compared to competitor
average, whereas in the rest of other months it was ~50% of our competitor average (Fig-2)
 Water Purifiers saw Y-o-Y growth of 45% in number of orders, 18% dip in cost per order and 27% dip
in CPCs
 Blue Star's share of GVs among the category was 4.5% in July which increased nearly by 4x during Oct
and reached 17% (Fig-3) (source: Amazon Pi)
 23% Increase in organic contribution compared to average of last 3 years
 Cresto Water Purifier from Blue Star was the most clicked SP ASIN on top searched keywords under
Water Purifiers category (Fig.4) (source: Amazon Pi)

Summarize this for graphics design

chosen.answer:
Blue Star Water Purifiers are looking to increase their market share and brand awareness while maintaining a low cost per order (CPO) and return on ad spend (ROAS). To achieve this, the brand is implementing an integrated growth plan on marketplaces and other digital channels. The objective is to gain a higher market share within the Water Purifier category and build a sustainable sales funnel. The target audience is prospects who have searched for Water Purifiers in the past and are currently searching for related keywords on Amazon and Flipkart.

The Situation Analysis shows that Blue Star is a relatively new entrant in the Water Purifier category and faces challenges in converting consumers from established brands like Kent and Aqua Guard by Eureka Forbes to their products. The major challenge is that their hero product, Aristo, which had the best conversion rate, went off the shelf just before the festival sale on marketplaces. The new product, Cresto, was introduced, but it required building an entire awareness, consideration, and trial funnel around it within a short time.

To achieve these objectives, Blue Star is implementing a bottom-to-mid approach strategy. The bottom funnel approach will identify the cash cow through all ad formats and targeting one ASIN per campaign. The top funnel approach includes segmenting campaigns based on keyword themes, high volume generic keywords, defense strategy, competition ASINs and category targeting, and leveraging sponsored display through retargeted mid-funnel customers.

The solution will result in tangible outputs such as a significant increase in brand searches, increased traffic relevance, and time spent on product detailed pages. The business results will include a 413% increase in orders for the newly introduced ASIN, nearly 80% GVs compared to the competitor average, a 45% increase in the number of orders, an 18% dip in cost per order, and a 27% dip in CPCs.

The graphics design should highlight the tangible and business results achieved by Blue Star's integrated growth plan on marketplaces and other digital channels. It can include charts, graphs, and tables that show the increase in brand searches, GVs, orders, cost per order, and CPCs, as well as the growth in market share within the Water Purifier category. The design should also emphasize the successful conversion of consumers from established brands to Blue Star's products.

conversation_input.content:
I have a doctorate level research proposal to write. The topic is "The Impact of Industrial Performance and benefits of Globalisation on HR in Nigeria.". The aim is To identify the effect of globalisation through the means of world integration, inter-dependency and interrelation of performance in Nigerian business sector In recent times. The objectives are 
I.To ascertain the extent to which organisational culture is superseded by the globalised idea of human resource management among Nigerian workers and industrial firms.
II. Examining cross-border industry collaboration as a means of organisational progress for Nigerian domestic business in the phase of globalisation.
III. To evaluate the benefit of globalisation for Nigerian workforce, employers, and competitiveness of productive capacity for the growth of established and up-and-coming businesses in Nigeria.


The rationale for the study is below:
The study highlights the lack of adequate literature for this evaluation by delving into the recently understudied component of performance appraisal. This business endeavour has sparked research into the enhancement of employee relations, performance evaluation of employees, and human resource management in Nigeria's industrial sectors. Based on the core concept that policies that prioritise natural and technological resources would surely be unsustainable in light of the expansion of economic activity and the diffusion of knowledge and technology, the focus on human resources management (HRM). As a result, it is asserted that there is a demand on human resources. (Schakowsky, 2002).

Despite the underlying theme of perceived marginalisation in the theory, it may seem unarguable that a country like Nigeria, the most populous country of African origin with over 140 million people, would see HRM-based strategy as crucial to economic success. History and current data demonstrate that the human capital of developing countries makes a major contribution to the development of industrialised countries. (Zikmund, 1998)

Although Kerr et al (1962a),Not many empirical studies have examined how globalisation has impacted human resource management in Nigeria, despite the fact that the value of human resources in national development is increasingly acknowledged. According to Kerr et al. (1962b), many developing nations rely on the results of studies that were conducted abroad since there aren't many empirically grounded studies on the effect of globalisation on HRM in such nations. chosen.answer:
Here's a condensed version of the research proposal in approximately 500 words, maintaining key references and points:

Research Proposal: The Impact of Industrial Performance and Benefits of Globalisation on HR in Nigeria

Aim: To identify the effect of globalisation through world integration, interdependency, and interrelation of performance in Nigeria's business sector.

Objectives:
1. Ascertain how globalised HRM ideas supersede organizational culture in Nigerian firms.
2. Examine cross-border industry collaboration for Nigerian business progress.
3. Evaluate globalisation benefits for Nigerian workforce, employers, and business competitiveness.

Rationale:
This study addresses the lack of adequate literature on performance appraisal in Nigeria's industrial sectors. It focuses on HRM, acknowledging that policies prioritizing natural and technological resources are unsustainable given economic expansion and knowledge diffusion (Schakowsky, 2002). Despite Nigeria's large population, few empirical studies have examined globalisation's impact on HRM (Kerr et al., 1962a,b,c). The Dependency Theory explains how rich nations maintain their living standards through poor countries' resources (Wilson, 2012b).

Literature Review:
Hofstede et al. (1990) and Sagiv & Schwartz (2007) emphasize that organizational culture dimensions differ from national culture dimensions but are interrelated. Ohamea et al. (1990) note that globalization and technological advancements continue to impact social and economic systems worldwide. The World Development Indicators (2007a) highlight both opportunities and challenges for developing nations in globalization.

Obadan (2008) points out that developing countries face persistent barriers in accessing developed markets. Wilson (2010a) argues that poor countries are at a disadvantage in global negotiations. Vincent (2012a,b) notes that globalization has both positive and negative effects on HRM in Nigeria, accelerating changes in HR practices and causing skilled worker migration.

Iyoha and Unugbro (2005) correlate globalization with changes in macroeconomic indicators. Owolabi (1998) emphasizes the need for global information networks to capitalize on market opportunities. Nemedia (1998) warns of the negative impact of trade liberalization on industrial sector growth in developing countries.

Ohamea et al. (1990) highlight the Marxist tradition's focus on economics as the primary analytical framework. Sano (1998) and Soludo (2007) point to human resources as key to rapid development in countries like Japan and Singapore. Stillwell et al. (2004) report that 2.9% of the world's population lived away from home for over a year.

The research adopts an exploratory approach, addressing novel problems with little prior research (Brown, 2006; Singh, 2007). It examines globalization's impact on Nigeria's HRM, acknowledging its profound influence on various aspects of life (Vincent, 2012). The study aims to investigate the connections between globalization and human resources, recognizing their competitive advantage for African countries, including Nigeria.

The proposed research aims to evaluate the impact of globalization on human resource management (HRM) in Nigeria's industrial sector, with a focus on performance appraisal. The research will examine the extent to which organizational culture is superseded by globalized HRM practices among Nigerian workers and firms, cross-border industry collaboration as a means of organizational progress, and the benefits of globalization for Nigerian workforce, employers, and business competitiveness. The rationale for the study is the lack of adequate literature on this topic and the importance of HRM-based strategies for economic success in Nigeria, a country with a large population and significant contributions to the development of industrialized countries.

The literature review highlights the relationship between organizational culture and national culture, with organizations operating under pressure from societal values. Globalization has brought opportunities and challenges to developing nations, with integration into the global economy being vital for long-term prosperity and poverty reduction. However, equal opportunity and unequal distribution of gains have been criticized, with globalization predominantly driven by the interests and needs of industrialized countries. Trade liberalization has had a significant negative impact on the growth of the industrial sector in developing countries.

The Marxist tradition's leftist researchers have used economics as their primary theoretical framework for analyzing how globalization affects various aspects of a nation's and organization's life. The use of human resources was the key to the success of the majority of the nations that climbed swiftly on the development ladder. The analysis of these nations suggests that people are the most important asset for economic development.

The research will critically evaluate recent and relevant research that has addressed similar issues. The impact of globalization on HRM has been studied in other countries, but limited research has been conducted in Nigeria. The proposed study aims to fill this gap by providing an empirical examination of the relationship between globalization and HRM in Nigeria's industrial sector.

The proposed research objectives include:

1. To ascertain the extent to which organizational culture is superseded by the globalized idea of human resource management among Nigerian workers and industrial firms.
2. Examining cross-border industry collaboration as a means of organizational progress for Nigerian domestic business in the phase of globalization.
3. To evaluate the benefit of globalization for Nigerian workforce, employers, and competitiveness of productive capacity for the growth of established and up-and-coming businesses in Nigeria.

The research will contribute to the literature on globalization and HRM by providing an empirical examination of the relationship between the two in Nigeria's industrial sector. The findings of the research will have practical implications for policy makers, HRM practitioners, and business leaders. The research will provide insights into how globalization can be leveraged to enhance HRM practices in Nigeria and improve organizational performance.
